'''Francis L. "Frank" Graves''' is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] applied social researcher. He is the founder and current president of [[EKOS Research Associates| EKOS Research Associates Inc.]]
==Education== Graves received a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[social anthropology]] from [[Carleton University]] in 1976, a [[Master of Arts]] in [[sociology]] from [[Carleton University]] in 1977, and has completed doctoral coursework and comprehensive exams in sociology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekos.com/about/team|title=The EKOS Team|publisher=[[EKOS Research Associates|EKOS Research Associates Inc]]|accessdate=2018-02-18}}</ref>
==Career== Graves is considered to be an expert in a number of fields related to public policy and program evaluation and has advised some of Canada's senior decision-makers, including the [[Office of the Prime Minister (Canada)|Prime Minister’s Office]], the [[Cabinet of Canada|federal cabinet]], the [[Clerk of the Privy Council (Canada)|Clerk of the Privy Council]], dozens of federal [[Deputy Minister (Canada)|deputy ministers]], and the [[Embassy of the United States in Ottawa|United States Ambassador to Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mria-arim.ca/OTTAWA/Programs.asp|title=MRIA - Ottawa Chapter|publisher=[http://www.mria-arim.ca The Marketing Research and Intelligence Association]|accessdate=2009-12-21}}</ref>
Graves has published widely in academic and mainstream publications. He has lectured at the [[Rotman School of Management]], the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government|Kennedy School at Harvard]], the [[University of Ottawa]], and the [[Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs]] in [[Washington, DC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nqi.ca/summit/bio.aspx|title=NQI Performance Excellence Summit |publisher=[http://www.nqi.ca/ National Quality Institute]|accessdate=2009-12-21}}</ref>
Graves is a frequent commentator in Canadian and American media. He has directed a number of public opinion research projects on behalf of the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]], [[The Toronto Star]], [[The Globe and Mail]], and [[La Presse (Canadian newspaper)|La Presse]]. He has made numerous television appearances on CBC’s [[Power & Politics| Power & Politics with Evan Solomon]], [[The National (CBC)|The National]], and [[CBC News: Politics|Politics with Don Newman]], as well as [[CTV Television Network|CTV]]’s [[Mike Duffy Live]]. He has also been part of the CBC’s Election Night coverage team.
In 2013, Graves was named a Fellow of the Marketing Research and Intelligence Association, the highest professional designation in the marketing research industry in Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mria-arim.ca/directories/mria-fellows|title=MRIA Fellows|publisher=[http://mria-arim.ca/ Marketing Research and Intelligence Association]|accessdate=2013-08-30}}</ref> He also serves on the advisory board at the [[Sprott School of Business]] at [[Carleton University]].
==Controversy== In April 2010, the [[Conservative Party of Canada]] accused Graves of giving partisan advice to the [[Liberal Party of Canada]], noting his donations to the party since 2003. An investigation conducted by the CBC ombudsman found no evidence to support these allegations, stating that personal donor history is not relevant to one's objectivity as a pollster.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ombudsman.cbc.radio-canada.ca/en/complaint-reviews/2010/frank-graves-on-a-possible-strategy-for-the-liberal-party|title=Frank Graves on a possible strategy for the Liberal Party|publisher=[http://www.cbc.ca/ombudsman CBC Office of the Ombudsman]|accessdate=2014-11-14}}</ref>

'''George Stevens Moore''' (April 1, 1905 – April 21, 2000) was a chairman of [[Citigroup]] from 1967 to 1970.
==Biography== Moore was born in [[Hannibal, Missouri]] and graduated from [[Yale University]] where he made money writing for the Yale Daily News and booking [[Broadway theatre|Broadway shows]] and tours to Europe for his classmates.
In 1927 he joined Farmers' Loan and Trust Company in New York City. The bank would merge with First National City Bank. He was President of Citibank (the predecessor to Citigroup) from 1959-1967 and later Chairman from 1967-1970. He was succeeded by Walter B. Wriston who was President from 1967-1970.
In 1963 Moore led an early effort by multinational corporations to create the world's first private investment company to promote the economic development of Latin America. This effort led to the formation of the [[Adela Investment Company]] in September 1964 and Moore served as a director.
Moore was President of the [[Metropolitan Opera]] Association in 1967 and dealt with financial problems as the company entered [[Lincoln Center]]. Cost-saving measures included raising ticket prices, delaying the season and eliminating free summer concerts in [[Central Park]].
Moore was the sole representative for financial interests of the [[Onassis family]] in the United States.
In 1987 he wrote "The Banker's Life" {{ISBN|0-393-33151-2}} detailing his experiences at the bank.
Mr. Moore was inducted into the Junior Achievement U.S. Business Hall of Fame in 1976. He was awarded Meritous Service to [https://web.archive.org/web/20100626090116/http://www.seas.yale.edu/alumni-hall-detail.php?id=55 Yale Science & Engineering Association - Hall of Achievement].
He died on April 21, 2000.<ref>{{cite news |author=Leslie Kaufman |coauthors= |title=George Moore, 95, Ex-Banker Who Led Metropolitan Opera |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/22/business/george-moore-95-ex-banker-who-led-metropolitan-opera.html |quote=George S. Moore, a banker who led the overseas expansion of what became Citibank and steered the Metropolitan Opera through turbulent financial times, died yesterday at his home in Sotograde, Spain. He was 95. ... In addition to his son by his first marriage, Mr. Moore is survived by his second wife, Charon C. Moore; their three children, daughters Christina Sendagorta and Maria Pia and a son, Steven C. Moore, all of Madrid; five grandchildren; and a great-grandson. |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=April 22, 2000 |accessdate=2012-09-16 }}</ref>
==Personal Life== He married his first wife, the Spanish-born Beatriz Bermejillo y Braniff, the Marquesada de Mohernando, in Mexico in 1938. From this marriage was born George Bermejillo Moore (1939-2015) who married Katharine Fairfax Lipson, descendant of the [[Schuyler family|Schuyler]], [[Van Rensselaer family|Van Renssalear]], and [[Bayard family|Bayard]] New York families.
==References== {{reflist}} {{start box}} {{s-bus}} {{succession box | before=[[James Stillman Rockefeller]] | title=[[List of Chief Executives of Citigroup|Chairman of Citigroup]] | years=1967–1970 | after=[[Walter B. Wriston]] }} {{end box}}

Mary Hopton }} '''Grey Brydges, 5th Baron Chandos''' ({{circa|1580}}{{snd}}10 August 1621) was an English nobleman and courtier. ==Early life== He was the only son of [[William Brydges, 4th Baron Chandos]], who died on 18 November 1602, and Mary Hopton, who was daughter of [[Sir Owen Hopton]]. He was M.P. for [[Cricklade (UK Parliament constituency)|Cricklade]], in 1597.{{DNB Cite|wstitle=Brydges, Grey}} Brydges and his family were friendly with [[Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex]]. His father visited Essex at [[Essex House (London)|Essex House]] on the Sunday morning (8 February 1601) of Essex's insurrection, but he was not deemed by the government to be implicated in the conspiracy. The son, Grey Brydges, was, however, suspected of immediate complicity, and was sent to the [[Fleet Prison]] with [[Henry Cuffe]] and others; but he was soon released. ==Courtier and grandee== Grey Brydges succeeded his father as '''[[Baron Chandos]]''' in 1602, attended King [[James I of England]]'s initial parliament on 19 March 1604, and was made [[Knight of the Bath]], when [[Charles I of England|Prince Charles Stewart]] was created Duke of York in January 1605. He visited [[Oxford]] with King James I, and was granted the degree of M.A. on 30 August 1605. On 2 July 1609, he was appointed keeper of [[Ditton Park]], Buckinghamshire, for life. He attended the funeral of [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales]], in 1612. Grey also took an active part in the court [[masque]]s and tournaments. It was reported at court on 9 September 1613 that a duel was to be fought by him and the King's favourite, [[James Hay, 1st Earl of Carlisle|Lord James Hay]]. He became [[Lord Lieutenant of Gloucestershire]] and was called the "King of the [[Cotswolds]]", owing to his generosity and his magnificent style of living at his residence, [[Sudeley Castle]].{{EB1911|inline=1|wstitle=Chandos, Barons and Dukes of |display=Chandos, Barons and Dukes of s.v. John Brydges, 1st Baron Chandos|volume=5|page=838}} ==Traveller== In 1608 he went travelling with [[Degory Wheare]].{{cite DNB|wstitle=Wheare, Degory}} In 1610 he was appointed one of the officers under [[Sir Edward Cecil]] in command of an expedition to the [[Low Countries]], in the [[War of the Jülich succession]]. The [[Emperor Rudolph II]]'s forces were besieging [[Juliers]], and the English had combined with Holland and France to protect the town. [[Lord Herbert of Cherbury]] was Chandos's companion through this campaign. Chandos lodged at Juliers with [[Sir Horace Vere]], but does not seem to have taken much part in the fighting. Afterwards he attended [[Antoine de Pluvinel]]'s academy in Paris, and then went to [[Blois]].Stoye, p. 32. ==Later life== On 23 July 1612, Grey Brydges visited [[Spa, Belgium|Spa]] in the [[Low Countries]], for his health; he had been there before during the Jülich campaign.Stoye, p. 207. On 14 July 1616, there was some talk of making him [[President of Wales]], and on 8 November 1617, he was appointed to receive ambassadors from [[Muscovy]], then in England. His health was still failing, and after trying in 1618, the waters of [[Newenham Mills]] in Warwickshire, he returned to Spa, where he died suddenly on 10 August 1621, while taking in the waters there. His body was brought to Sudeley Castle, and buried there. An elegy for him was written by [[Sir John Beaumont]]. ==''Horae Subsecivae''== Chandos has been regarded by [[Horace Walpole]] and others as the author of some essays, ''Horae Subsecivae''. These were published by [[Edward Blount]], and from topical references would appear to have been written about 1615. The attribution is moot: [[Michael Lort]] and [[Samuel Egerton Brydges]] supported Walpole's view. [[Anthony à Wood]] and [[White Kennett]] had earlier stated that Gilbert Cavendish, eldest son of [[William Cavendish, 1st Earl of Devonshire]], was the author of the work. Copies are extant with the name of Lord Chandos inscribed on the title-page in seventeenth-century handwriting. [[Edmond Malone]] and [[Thomas Park (antiquary)|Thomas Park]], the editor of Walpole, attributed the book on the grounds of Gilbert's age to [[William Cavendish, 2nd Earl of Devonshire|William]], a brother. A modern view agrees to the extent that 10 of the essays can be shown to have been written by William (for his father) in 1615, at a time when [[Thomas Hobbes]] was his tutor. (There is another view, which is that this collection is Hobbes's own work.) The published essays come as 12 shorter pieces (the 10 by William being among those); and four longer ones, now attributed one to William (on flattery, based on a piece from 1611) and three to Hobbes.A. P. Martinich, ''Hobbes: A Biography'' (1999), p. 37 and pp. 43–44. ==Family== On 28 February 1607, he married [[Anne Stanley, Countess of Castlehaven|Lady Anne Stanley]], daughter of [[Ferdinando Stanley, 5th Earl of Derby]] and [[Alice Spencer, Countess of Derby|Lady Alice Spencer]]. His wife Anne, a great-great-granddaughter of [[Henry VIII of England|King Henry VIII]]'s sister, Princess [[Mary Tudor, Queen of France|Mary Tudor]], had been [[heir presumptive|heiress presumptive]] to the throne of England; she was, however, passed over for King [[James VI and I|James VI of Scotland]]. The couple had the following five children: * Robert Brydges (b. 1611), died young. * Anne Brydges (b. 1612): she did marry, reputedly to a Mr Torteson but little is known about her later life and whether there were any issue. Issue has never been ruled out, there is little firm evidence about her life after childhood. * Elizabeth Brydges (1619–1678), married her stepbrother, [[James Tuchet, 3rd Earl of Castlehaven]]. * [[George Brydges, 6th Baron Chandos]] (1620–1654), married firstly, Lady Susan Montagu, daughter of [[Henry Montagu, 1st Earl of Manchester]]; married secondly, Lady Jane Savage, daughter of [[John Savage, 2nd Earl Rivers]]. From both his wives, he had altogether six daughters, but no sons. * [[Baron Chandos#Barons Chandos, second creation (1554)|William Brydges, 7th Baron Chandos]] (1621–1676), married Susan Kerr. No issue. ==References== *Date of birth [http://www.stirnet.com/HTML/genie/british/bb4fz/brydges02.htm#link stirnet.com]. Retrieved 29 May 2007 *John Stoye (1989), ''English Travellers Abroad 1604–1667'' ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ;Attribution {{DNB|wstitle=Brydges, Grey}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Henry Berkeley, 7th Baron Berkeley|The Lord Berkeley]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Lord Lieutenant of Gloucestershire]]|years=1613–1621}} {{s-aft|after=[[William Compton, 1st Earl of Northampton|The Earl of Northampton]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[John Pointz|Sir John Poyntz]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Custos Rotulorum of Gloucestershire]]|years=''Date unknown'' – 1621}} {{s-aft|after=[[Sir John Bridgeman|John Bridgeman]]}} {{s-reg|en}} {{s-bef|before=[[William Brydges, 4th Baron Chandos|William Brydges]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Baron Chandos]]|creation=2nd creation|years=1602–1621}} {{s-aft|after=[[George Brydges, 6th Baron Chandos|George Brydges]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chandos, Grey Brydges, 5th Baron}} [[Category:1580s births]] [[Category:1621 deaths]] [[Category:Barons in the Peerage of England]] [[Category:Duellists]] [[Category:Lord-Lieutenants of Gloucestershire]] [[Category:English MPs 1597–1598]] [[Category:17th-century English nobility]] [[Category:People of the Tudor period]] [[Category:People of the Stuart period]] [[Category:Prisoners in Fleet Prison]] [[Category:Members of Parliament for Cricklade]] [[Category:Brydges/Brugge family|Gr]] [[Category:Burials at St Mary's Chapel, Sudeley Castle]]

'''Hanna Alwan''', [[Congregation of the Lebanese Maronite Missionaries|MLM]] (born on 20 September 1954 in Aytou, [[Lebanon]]) is Curial bishop of the [[Maronite Catholic Patriarchate of Antioch]].<ref name="gcatholic">{{cite web|url=http://www.gcatholic.org/hierarchy/data/bishops-AG.htm#46395 |title=Bishops who are not Ordinaries of Sees: AG… – AL… |publisher=gcatholic.org|accessdate=2016-01-20}}</ref>
==Life==
Hanna Alwan joined the [[Congregation of the Lebanese Maronite Missionaries|MLM]] and made his [[religious vows]] in 1979. On 18 July 1981 Alwan received his priestly ordination. The Synod of the [[Maronite Church]] elected him on 6 June 2011 Curial Bishop of Antioch. [[Pope Benedict XVI]] confirmed his appointment and named him on 13 August 2011 [[titular bishop]] of Sarepta dei Maroniti.
[[List of Maronite Patriarchs|Maronite Patriarch of Antioch]], [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|Cardinal]] [[Bechara Boutros al-Rahi]], [[Mariamite Maronite Order|OMM]], ordained him on 16 September of the same year to the episcopate. His co-consecrators were [[Joseph Hitti]], Eparch of Saint Maron of Sydney, and [[Georges Bou-Jaoudé]], [[Congregation of the Mission|CM]], Archeparch of Tripoli.

{{other people|Henry Bate}} '''Henry Bate''' or '''Hendrik Baten''' ('''of Mechelen''' or '''of Malines''') a.k.a. '''Henricus Batenus''' ('''Mechliniensis''')<ref group="N">In all five languages that this English language Wikipedia inspected, the first name and family name may occur with or without mentioning his place of origin, and remarkably, apart from Dutch and rarely in Latin, the first name and origin can be found without his family name. In his native Dutch language and in German, the latter appears as either ''Baten'' or ''Bate''; in French and English the latter spelling clearly prevails. Hence in these languages he is referred to as ''Hendrik Bate[n] [van Mechelen]'', ''Heinrich [Bate[n]] von Mecheln'', ''Henri [Bate] de Malines'', and ''Henry [Bate] of Mechelen'' respectively although in particular in English, the French translation of his birthplace is equally common: ''of Malines'' (and in German one very rarely finds ''de Malines'' and once ''von Malines''). Texts in any language may show his Latinized name ''Henricus Batenus [Mechliniensis]''.</ref> (24 March 1246 in [[Mechelen]] – after 1310 in [[Tongerloo]]) was a [[Flanders|Flemish]] philosopher, theologian, astronomer, astrologer, poet, and musician.
He was [[Master of Arts]] of the [[University of Paris]] before 1274. He was a pupil of [[Thomas Aquinas]], he became a canon and cantor of the [[Cathedral of Saint-Lambert]], [[Liège]] before 1289.
As astronomer, he made [[astrolabe]]s, and wrote ''Magistralis compositio astrolabii'', dedicated to his friend [[William of Moerbeke]]. He drew up astronomical tables: the ''Tabule Mechlinenses'', from around 1285-1295, and a 1290 work, ''De erroribus tabularum Alphonsi'', which pointed out errors in the [[Alfonsine tables]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | author = [[Karl Christian Bruhns]] | title = Baten, Heinrich | encyclopedia = [[Allgemeine Deutsche Biographie]] | volume = 2 | year = 1875 | page = 132 | url = http://de.wikisource.org/wiki/ADB:Baten,_Heinrich|language=de}}</ref> While in Rome in 1292, he wrote commentaries on the astrological works of [[Abraham ibn Ezra]] and [[Albumasar]].
He became tutor to [[Guy of Avesnes|Guy de Hainaut]], brother of Count [[Jean d'Avesnes]], for whom he wrote, between 1285 and 1305, a ''Speculum divinorum et quorundam naturalium'' (On the Unity of Natural).
Around 1309, he retired with the [[Premonstratensians]] of Tongerloo, where he ended his days.
==Notes== <references group="N" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *Benoît Beyer de Ryke: [http://dev.ulb.ac.be/philo/urhm/pdf/henribate.pdf Biography (PDF)] {{fr icon}} * [http://fr.wikisource.org/wiki/Biographie_nationale_de_Belgique/Tome_1/BATEN,_Henri BATEN,_Henri] (which mentions H.B. of Malines as author of another work (or an otherwise renamed edition) pointing out the errors in the Alphonsine tables){{fr icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110723005436/http://www-cgi.uni-regensburg.de/Fakultaeten/phil_Fak_I/Philosophie/Gesch_Phil/alcuin/philosopher.php?id=933 Biographical and bibliographical notes], in: Alcuin Database of Scholastic Authors, Regensburg. {{de icon}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''James Tilly Matthews''' (1770 – 10 January 1815) was a London [[Tea in the United Kingdom|tea broker]], originally from [[Wales]] and of Huguenot descent,<ref>{{cite book|title=The History of Bethlem Hospital|last1= Andrews|first1 =Jonathan|last2=Briggs|first2=Asa|last3=Porter |first3=Roy|first4 =Penny|last4= Tucker|first5=Keir|last5=Waddington|publisher=Routledge|location=London|year=1997|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=7mqBPxwIkW8C&pg=PA406 406]|isbn=0415017734|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7mqBPxwIkW8C}}</ref> who was committed to [[Bethlem Royal Hospital|Bethlem]] (colloquially Bedlam) [[psychiatric hospital]] in 1797. His is considered to be the first fully documented case of [[paranoid schizophrenia]].<ref name=Carpenter1989>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0010-440X(89)90058-8 | last1 = Carpenter | first1 = P. K. | title = Descriptions of schizophrenia in the psychiatry of Georgian Britain: [[John Haslam (physician)|John Haslam]] and James Tilly Matthews | journal = Comprehensive psychiatry | volume = 30 | issue = 4 | pages = 332–338 | year = 1989 | pmid = 2667883 }}</ref>
==Biography==
===Voyage to France=== In the early 1790s, concerned at the likelihood of war between Britain and France, Matthews travelled to France with the radical [[David Williams (philosopher)|David Williams]] who was acquainted with such [[Girondist]]s as [[Jacques Pierre Brissot]] and [[Charles-François Lebrun, duc de Plaisance|Le Brun]]. Williams made efforts at mediation which failed, whereupon Matthews took the lead. He gained the trust of the French government for a short time.
On 2 June 1793 the Girondists were displaced by the [[Jacobin (politics)|Jacobins]] and Matthews fell under suspicion for his Girondist associations and also because he was suspected of being a [[double agent]]. He was arrested and imprisoned for three years during the height of [[Reign of Terror|The Terror]] and was reportedly terrified of the guillotine, like all others. This lasted until 1796 when the French authorities concluded that he was a [[lunatic]] and released him.<ref name="parmod">{{cite book | last = Trotter | first = David | authorlink = | author2 = | title = Paranoid Modernism: Literary Experiment, Psychosis, and the Professionalization of English Society | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | year = 2001 | location = | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-19-818755-6}}</ref>
===Committal=== Returning to London, Matthews wrote two letters to [[Lord Liverpool]], in which he accused the [[Home Secretary]] of treason and complained about conspiracies directed against his life. After interrupting a debate in the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]] by shouting "Treason" at Lord Liverpool from the Public Gallery, he was arrested and held at [[Tothill Fields Bridewell]], a secure [[workhouse|house of correction]] in Tothill Fields, [[Westminster]] before being admitted to the [[Bethlem Royal Hospital|Bethlem]] (Bedlam) psychiatric hospital on 28 January 1797.<ref name="parmod"/> Upon examination he declared that he had taken part in secret affairs of state (referring to his efforts in France), but had been betrayed and abandoned by [[William Pitt the Younger|William Pitt]]'s administration.<ref name="nth">{{cite web | last = Jay | first = Mike | authorlink = | author2 = | title = The Air Loom Gang: James Tilly Matthews and his visionary madness | work = | publisher = Nthposition Magazine | year = 2003 | url = http://www.nthposition.com/theairloomgangjames.php | format = | doi = | accessdate = 31 January 2008}}</ref>
In 1809 his family and friends petitioned for his release, on the grounds that he was no longer insane, but their petition was rejected by the Bethlem authorities. They therefore took out a suit of [[habeas corpus]] and two doctors, [[George Birkbeck]] and [[Henry Clutterbuck]] examined Matthews, declaring him sane. [[John Haslam (physician)|John Haslam]], the resident [[apothecary]] at Bethlem, begged to differ and maintained that Matthews' [[delusion]]s, particularly on political matters, rendered him a danger both to public figures and the general public.<ref name="parmod"/>
===''Illustrations of Madness''=== [[File:Illustrations of madness... Wellcome L0047393.jpg|thumb|right|Title page]] In 1810 John Haslam produced the book ''Illustrations of Madness'' (original title: ''Illustrations of Madness: Exhibiting a Singular Case of Insanity, And a No Less Remarkable Difference in Medical Opinions: Developing the Nature of An Assailment, And the Manner of Working Events; with a Description of Tortures Experienced by Bomb-Bursting, Lobster-Cracking and Lengthening the Brain. Embellished with a Curious Plate'').<ref>{{cite book | last = Haslam | first = John | authorlink = John Haslam (physician) | author2 = | title = Illustrations of Madness | publisher = [[Routledge]] | year = 1988 | location = | pages = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-415-00637-6}}</ref> Haslam intended to settle the dispute over Matthews' sanity; his book contains verbatim accounts of Matthew's beliefs and hallucinatory experiences and is considered the original description of the symptoms of paranoid schizophrenia.<ref>{{cite web | last = Howard | first = Robert | authorlink = | author2 = | title = Psychiatry in pictures | work = | publisher = [[British Journal of Psychiatry]] | year = 2001 | url = http://bjp.rcpsych.org/cgi/content/full/179/3/0 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 31 January 2008}}</ref> The book documented the first full study of a single psychiatric patient in medical history and has become a classic in the medical literature.
===The "Air Loom"=== [[Image:Airloom.gif|thumb|right|200px|Matthews's illustration of the Air Loom.]]Matthews believed that a gang of criminals and spies skilled in [[pneumatic chemistry]] had taken up residence at [[London Wall]] in [[Moorfields]] (close to Bethlem) and were tormenting him by means of rays emitted by a machine called the "Air Loom" or gaseous charge generator. The torments induced by the rays included "Lobster-cracking", during which the circulation of the blood was prevented by a [[magnetic field]]; "Stomach-skinning" and "Apoplexy-working with the nutmeg grater" which involved the introduction of fluids into the skull. His persecutors bore such names as "the Middleman" (who operated the Air Loom), "the Glove Woman" and "Sir Archy" (who acted as "repeaters" or "active worriers" to enhance Matthews' torment or record the machine's activities) and their leader, a man called "Bill, or the King".
Matthews' delusions had a definite political slant: he claimed that the purpose of this gang was espionage, and that there were many other such gangs armed with Air Looms all over London, using "pneumatic practitioners" to "premagnetize" potential victims with "volatile magnetic fluid". According to Matthews, their chief targets (apart from himself) were leading government figures. By means of their "rays" they could influence ministers' thoughts and [[Telepathy|read their minds]]. Matthews declared that William Pitt was "not half" susceptible to these attacks<ref name="parmod"/> and held that these gangs were responsible for the British military disasters at [[British invasions of the Río de la Plata#Second invasion - 1807|Buenos Aires]] in 1807 and [[Walcheren Campaign|Walcheren]] in 1809 and also for the [[Nore Mutiny]] of 1797.
In 1814 Matthews was moved to "Fox's London House", a private asylum in [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], where he became a popular and trusted patient. His delusions appeared to have stopped. The asylum's owner, Dr. Fox, regarded him as sane. Matthews assisted with bookkeeping and gardening until his death on 10 January 1815.<ref name="nth"/>
==Significance of the Air Loom Gang affair== Although it is impossible to make an unequivocal diagnosis of a person long since deceased, Matthews' description of his torment by the "Air Loom Gang" reads as a classic example of [[Paranoia|paranoid]] [[persecutory delusion]]s experienced as part of a [[psychotic]] episode. From this, it can be concluded that his disorder was most likely [[schizophrenia]], although retrospective diagnoses should be treated with caution.
It should also be noted that while Haslam kept notes on Matthews, Matthews kept notes on Haslam and his treatment in Bethlem. This formed part of the evidence looked at by the House of Commons 'Committee On the Better Regulation of Madhouses in England' in 1815, the findings of which led to Haslam's dismissal and reform of the treatment of patients in the Bethlem Hospital.
Matthews was also important in the history of psychiatry for more practical reasons. During his involuntary confinement he took part in a public competition to design plans for the rebuilding of Bethlem hospital. Bethlem's governors thought so well of the 46 pages of designs submitted by Matthews that they paid him £50 ({{Inflation|UK|50|1810|r=-1|fmt=eq|cursign=£}}).{{Inflation-fn|UK}} {{verify source|date=December 2013}} and the drawings finally used to build the new hospital show some features proposed by Matthews.<ref name="parmod"/>
==Fictional representations== *''Haslam's Key'', a play written by journalist [[Danny O'Brien (journalist)|Danny O'Brien]] and performed at the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] in 1993, imagined Matthews as a forerunner of modern science fiction authors. The titular "key" was a wooden spoon-like device invented by [[John Haslam (physician)|John Haslam]], the documenter of Matthew's delusions, which was used to force-feed Bedlam patients. *Richard Hayden's novel ''The Influencing Engine'' (1996) is a fantasy loosely based on aspects of Matthews' life. *In 2002, the British artist [[Rod Dickinson]] built a re-creation of the air loom from Matthews' original plans. *[[Greg Hollingshead]]'s novel ''Bedlam'' (2004) concerns the changing relationship between John Haslam and Matthews and is narrated in first-person from the perspective of Haslam, Matthews, and Matthews' wife. *The ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation|CSI]]'' episode "Lab Rats" (2007), [[Gil Grissom|Grissom]] uses Matthews' condition as an analogy in describing [[The Miniature Killer]], a [[serial killer]] obsessed with bleach. *[[Robert Rankin]]'s 2007 novel, ''[[The Da-da-de-da-da Code]]'', features a group of villains known as the Air Loom Gang, as well as a doctor named Doctor Archy, a pub called "The Middle Man" and a beer called "King Billy". * The first album from [[Aberystwyth]] band [[The Lowland Hundred (band)|The Lowland Hundred]] features a song called "The Air Loom", which references the affair. * The game ''[[Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs]]'' from 2013 makes several references to both James Tilly Matthews, the Air Loom and Bedlam. * Avant-garde black metal band Denizens released a 2013 EP titled ''On The Origins of the Influencing Machine'' directly referencing Matthews.
==See also== * [[On the Origin of the "Influencing Machine" in Schizophrenia|Influencing Machine]] * [[Mind control]] * [[Persecutory delusion]]

==Further reading== * [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/12548 Jonathan Andrews, "Haslam, John (bap. 1764, d. 1844)", ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004.] * [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&db=PubMed&list_uids=2667883&dopt=Abstract Carpenter, P.K., "Descriptions of Schizophrenia in the Psychiatry of Georgian Britain: John Haslam and James Tilly Matthews", ''Comprehensive Psychiatry'', 30 (4), 332–338. 1989.] * Gere, C., "The technologies and politics of delusion: an interview with artist Rod Dickinson", ''Studies in History and Philosophy of Science Part C: Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Sciences'', Vol.35, No.2, (June 2004), pp. 333–349. * [[John Haslam (physician)|Haslam, J.]], ''Illustrations of Madness: Exhibiting a Singular Case of Insanity, and No Less Remarkable Difference of Medical Opinion: Developing the Nature of An Assailment, and the Manner of Working Events; with a Description of the Tortures Experienced by Bomb-Bursting, Lobster-Cracking, and Lengthening the Brain, etc.'', G. Hayden, (London), 1810. * Howard, R., "James Tilly Matthews in London and Paris 1793: His First Peace Mission — in His Own Words", ''History of Psychiatry'', Vol.2, No.5, (March 1991), pp. 53–69. * Howard, R., "Useful or useless architecture? A dimension of the relationship between the Georgian schizophrenic James Tilly Matthews and his doctor, John Haslam", ''Psychiatric Bulletin'', Vol.14, No.10, (October 1990), pp. 620–622. * Jay, M., The Air Loom Gang, Bantam Press, (London), 2003. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110606062701/http://www.forteantimes.com/features/articles/450/shadow_of_the_air_loom.html Jay, M., "The Shadow of the Air Loom"], ''[[Fortean Times]]'', No.220, (March 2007), pp. 52–54. * Matthews, J.T., ''Useful Architecture'', S. Bass, (London), 1812. * Pilkington, M., "The Air Loom", ''Fortean Times'', No.170, (May 2003), pp. 40–43. * [https://doi.org/10.1353/sec.2010.0299 Porter, R., "Reason, Madness, and the French Revolution"], ''Studies in Eighteenth Century Culture'', Vol.20, (1991), pp. 55–79. * Suzuki, A., "My own private England – the madness of James Tilly Matthews and of his times", ''History of Psychiatry'', (December 2005), Vo.16, No.4, pp. 497–502. * Trotter, David. ''Paranoid Modernism: Literary Experiment, Psychosis, and the Professionalization of English Society'', Oxford University Press, (Oxford), 2001. * Williams, D., "The Missions of David Williams and James Tilly Matthews to England (1793)", ''The English Historical Review'', Vol.53, No.212, (October 1938), pp. 651–668.

'''Joe Dallas''' (born 1954) is a prominent figure in the [[ex-gay movement]] and an advocate of [[reparative therapy]] from a [[Christianity|Christian]] perspective.
==Career== Dallas is founder of Genesis Counseling in [[Tustin, California]], which specializes in [[conversion therapy]].<ref name="joedallas.com">[http://www.joedallas.com Joe Dallas l Genesis Counseling l Sexual Addiction Recovery<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Dallas is the keynote speaker at one of the monthly weekend retreats on sexual purity titled "Every Man's Battle" (sponsored by New Life Ministries).<ref>{{cite news |title=‘Love Won Out’ conference coming to Southern California |publisher=Christian Examiner |url=http://www.christianexaminer.com/Articles/Articles%20Sep07/Art_Sep07_13.html |date=September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929155104/http://www.christianexaminer.com/Articles/Articles%20Sep07/Art_Sep07_13.html |archivedate=2011-09-29 |df= }}</ref> Dallas focuses on healing "Sexual Addiction, Responding to Pro-gay Theology, Ministering to Parents of Lesbians/Gays, Developing Ministerial Responses to Homosexuals, Apologetics Approaches to the ‘Gay Debate’"<ref name="Exodus International - Joe Dallas">[http://www.exodus.to/content/view/371/0/ Exodus International - Joe Dallas<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He has also written three books and discussed them in the media.<ref>{{cite news |title = Pro-Homosexual Theology |url = http://www.ncfpc.org/radioshowarchives2007.html |publisher = [[North Carolina]] [[Family Policy Council]] |date = September 1, 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080514132903/http://www.ncfpc.org/radioshowarchives2007.html |archivedate = May 14, 2008 |df = }}{{cite web |url=http://www.ncfpc.org/Podcast/NCFPC-070901-Dallas.mp3 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727113537/http://www.ncfpc.org/Podcast/NCFPC-070901-Dallas.mp3 |archivedate=2011-07-27 |df= }}</ref>
Genesis Counseling claims that [[homosexuality]] can be altered and that they are "Reclaiming Godly Sexuality through the Saving Work of Jesus Christ, The Sancifying Work of the Holy Spirit and the Body Ministry of the Christian Church."<ref name="joedallas.com"/> Dallas frequently denounces [[gay rights]] movements as part of the "[[homosexual agenda]]",<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/exodus-freedom-speaker-warns-of-the-gay-gospel-28160/ |title=Exodus Freedom Speaker Warns of 'The Gay Gospel' |date=June 25, 2007 |first=Lillian |last=Kwon |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130119073647/http://www.christianpost.com/article/20070625/28160_Exodus_Freedom_Speaker_Warns_of_'The_Gay_Gospel'.htm |archive-date=2013-01-19 |accessdate=2018-05-27 |deadurl=unfit |publisher=The Christian Post}}</ref> claiming "I’m not sure we can defeat the pro-gay lobby or prevent their goals from being achieved. But win or lose, I don’t want to stand before God and say I did nothing when I had the opportunity to fight."<ref name="exgaywatch.com">Joe Dallas to Exodus Ministries: Fight Gays. Discriminate. by: Mike Airhart http://www.exgaywatch.com/wp/2005/05/joe-dallas-to-e/</ref>
Dallas has encouraged [[Exodus International]] to oppose measures outlawing discrimination based on sexual orientation.<ref name="exgaywatch.com"/> He served for three years as Chair of the Exodus International Board of Directors and is a member of the [[American Association of Christian Counselors]].<ref name="Exodus International - Joe Dallas"/>
Dallas is a featured speaker at [[Focus on the Family]]'s "Love Won Out" conference.<ref>http://www.genesiscounseling.org/about-joe-dallas.cfm</ref>
===Books=== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070111040832/http://www.harvesthousepublishers.com/books_nonfictionbook.cfm?ProductID=6912118 ''Desires in Conflict: Hope for Men Who Struggle with Sexual Identity''] (2003) {{ISBN|978-0-7369-1211-2}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070111040502/http://www.harvesthousepublishers.com/books_nonfictionbook.cfm?ProductID=6912010 ''When Homosexuality Hits Home: What to Do When a Loved One Says They're Gay''] (2004) {{ISBN|978-0-7369-1201-3}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070111041053/http://www.harvesthousepublishers.com/books_nonfictionbook.cfm?ProductID=6918343 ''The Gay Gospel?: How Pro-Gay Advocates Misread the Bible''] (2007) {{ISBN|978-0-7369-1834-3}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Joe Werner | image = JoeWerner-BACMcover.jpg | alt = Joe Werner | caption = Joe Werner CD | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = Joseph Edward Werner <ref name="WernerBACM"></ref> | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1909|9|20}}<ref name="RT1978">{{cite news |date=June 18, 1978 |title=Services For Joe Werner In Crowley Monday |newspaper=Rayne Acadian Tribune |location=Acadia Parish Library }}</ref> <ref name="WernerBACM">{{Cite AV media notes |title=Joe Werner Early Cajun Artist |url=http://country-music-archive.com/country-cds/joe-werner-early-cajun-artist-bacm-cd-543|year=2016 |access-date=February 10, 2017 |first=Kevin |last=Coffey |type=liner notes |publisher=BACM |id=543}}</ref> | death_date = {{death date and age|1975|6|10|1909|09|20}}<ref name="RT1978"></ref> |death_place = [[Ft. Worth, Texas]] | birth_place = [[Rayne, Louisiana]]<ref name="RT1978"></ref> <ref name="WernerBACM"></ref> | instrument = [[guitar]], [[harmonica]], [[vocals]], [[whistling]] | genre = [[Cajun music|Cajun]], [[country music]], Western [[string band]] | occupation = Musician, [[entertainer]] | associated_acts = [[Hackberry Ramblers]], Louisiana Rounders, Joe's Acadians, Thibodeaux Boys | website = }}
'''Joseph Edward Werner'''<ref name="RT1978"></ref> <ref name="WernerBACM"></ref> (September 20, 1909, [[Rayne, Louisiana]] – June 10, 1978, [[Ft. Worth, Texas]])<ref name="RT1978"></ref> <ref name="WernerBACM"></ref> was a [[Cajun music]]ian most remembered for his tune "Wondering" made famous by [[Webb Pierce]]. He played for many years with the group [[Hackberry Ramblers]] as they were known as Riverside Ramblers as well as in several Cajun groups of his own. Although his career spanned only two years, 1937 and 1938, his French and English tunes influenced many Cajun musicians in Louisiana for years.
==Early life== Joe was exposed to music in his early life having many musicians in his family. His parents, Max and Martha Werner with both German immigrants, with Max being a veteran of the [[Spanish–American War]].<ref name="WernerBACM"></ref> He recalled back when he was a barefooted kid, he told his father before Christmas that he wanted Santa Claus to bring him a harmonica. He got his harmonica and he started "fooling" with music. Year after year, the Christmas request was the same, and year after year, Santa Claus came through with another harmonica.<ref name="CDS1952">{{cite news |date=1952 |title=Werner's Wondering Finds New Popularity |newspaper=Crowley Daily Signal |location=Acadia Parish Library }}</ref> Throughout his school years, he performed on stage as both a vaudeville [[black face]] actor in minstrel shows and as a whistling, guitar playing, singing musician.<ref name="CDS1935">{{cite news |date=October 18, 1935|title=St. Joseph Fair Will Open On Saturday |newspaper=Rayne Tribune |location=Acadia Parish Library }}</ref> <ref name="RT1927">{{cite news |date=May 7, 1927|title=Large Crowd Attends Community Singing |newspaper=Rayne Tribune |location=Acadia Parish Library }}</ref> At some point in the early 30s, he moved to [[Crowley, Louisiana]] where he participated in talent competitions in the city, even travelling to Chicago with fellow actor and entertainer, S.L. Ross.
==String band era== In 1935, the Hackberry Ramblers began recording music for [[RCA Victor]] records on their budget [[Bluebird Records]] label. Joe got married in 1936 and late that year, he began playing with the band. In 1937, the group was invited to record in [[New Orleans]] for a session where several English tunes were sung under the band name "Riverside Ramblers". Joe sang and played a tune he claimed he learned from a travelling hobo called "Wondering". According to Joe: {{Quote|text=It was back in my courtin' days. One day I sat down and started picking away at the guitar and playing the harmonica and the tune fell together. I worked out the words the same way. It was in Paco's Cafe over in Rayne. I had the song and words before I left Paco's that night.<ref name="CDS1952"></ref> |author=Joe Werner }} The song was an instant success and became a hit record for Bluebird that year. However, the listening public, including possibly RCA executives themselves, didn't realize that his acclaimed original tune was actual a cover of a [[Jack Golding]] song he made in 1928 called "Wondering". Joe's success caught the attention of [[Decca Records|Decca]] A&R representatives. Without the Ramblers' consent, Joe signed over the rights of the song to Decca, recording a follow-up song called "Answer to Wondering" in 1937. Over the next year, he left the Hackberry Ramblers and started his own group using a variety of musicians including [[Papa Cairo]], Wayne Perry, [[Happy Fats]], and [[Doc Guidry]]. He had 3 more recording sessions with Bluebird and Decca, changing musicians and band names throughout. However, by the end of 1938, most major labels were no longer interested in recording Cajun music, ending Joe's recording career. Alongside the 12 sides recorded with the Ramblers, Joe accomplished 56 more recordings during this time, including "Crap Shooter's Hop" and "Rang Tang Bully". <ref>{{cite book |last1=Russell |first1=Tony |last2=Pinson |first2=Bob |date=September 26, 2008 |title=Country Music Records: A Discography, 1921-1942 |publisher=Oxford University Press |edition=1st |isbn=978-0195366211}}</ref>
==After World War II== With his recording years behind him, Joe started a family and got a job working for the local newspaper. Joe settled into playing music on Crowley's radio station [[KSIG (AM)|KSIG]], where he would often feature his three children accompanying him. This came to a halt in 1951 when his oldest son, Richard, was killed in a tragic auto accident.<ref name="CDS1951">{{cite news |date=April 28, 1951|title=Richard Werner Killed In Bike-Truck Mishap |newspaper=Crowley Daily Signal |location=Acadia Parish Library }}</ref> The following year, [[Webb Pierce]] heard Werner's recording and turned it into one of his hit songs, spending four weeks at the top in 1952. Joe continued to write columns for the newspaper and made occasional appearances in town until he moved to Fort Worth, Texas with his wife Anne. He died in 1978.
==Discography==
* Joe Werner: Early Cajun Artist (BACM CD 543, 2016) * CAJUN-Rare & Authentic (JSP, 2008) * Cajun Country Volume 2: More Hits From The Swamp (JSP, 2005)

{{short description|Scottish-American Presbyterian minister and a Founding Father of the United States}} {{For|the actor|John Witherspoon (actor)}} {{Infobox person |name = John Witherspoon |occupation =[[Clergyman]] and [[Theology|theologian]] |known_for = |image = Peale, Charles Willson, John Witherspoon (1723-1794), President (1768-94).jpg |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = John Knox Witherspoon |birth_date = {{Birth date|1723|2|5|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Gifford, East Lothian|Gifford]], [[Scotland]] |nationality = American/Scottish |spouse = |death_date = {{death date and age|1794|11|15|1722|2|5|mf=y}} |death_place = Near [[Princeton, New Jersey|Princeton]], [[Mercer County, New Jersey|Mercer County]], [[New Jersey]] |resting_place = Princeton Cemetery |alma mater = [[University of Edinburgh]] |signature = John Witherspoon signature.png }} '''John Knox Witherspoon''' (February 5, 1723 – November 15, 1794) was a [[Scottish-American]] [[Presbyterian]] minister and a [[Founding Fathers of the United States|Founding Father of the United States]].<ref>{{Cite book|last= Longfield |first= Bradley J. | title = Presbyterians and American Culture: A History | pages=40–41 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=wDdybyrOc-IC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |year= 2013 | publisher= Westminster John Knox Press | location = Louisville, Kentucky | accessdate = November 6, 2015}}.</ref> Witherspoon embraced the concepts of [[Scottish common sense realism]], and while president of the College of New Jersey (1768–1794; now [[History of Princeton University|Princeton University]]), became an influential figure in the development of the United States' national character. Politically active, Witherspoon was a delegate from [[New Jersey]] to the [[Second Continental Congress]] and a signatory to the July 4, 1776, [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]]. He was the only active clergyman and the only college president to sign the Declaration.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = Princeton University |title = Princeton Presidents |url = http://www.princeton.edu/pr/facts/presidents/09.htm |accessdate = 2010-07-16 }}</ref> Later, he signed the [[Articles of Confederation]] and supported [[ratification#Ratification in the United States Constitution|ratification]] of the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]]. In 1789 he was convening [[Chairman|moderator]] of the First [[Presbyterian polity#General assembly|General Assembly]] of the [[Presbyterian Church in the United States of America]].
== Early life and ministry in Scotland ==
[[File:The grave of Rev James Alexander Witherspoon, Gifford.jpg|thumb|300px|The grave of Rev James Alexander Witherspoon, Gifford]] John Knox Witherspoon<ref>{{cite book |last=Pyne |first=F. W. |title=Descendants of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence |location=Rockport, Maine |publisher=Picton press |volume=3 Pt. 1 |page=93 |edition=2nd }}</ref> was born at [Aberdeenshire], [[Scotland]], as the eldest child of the Reverend James Alexander Witherspoon and Anne Walker,<ref>Witherspoon's mother's name has alternatively been spelled as "Anna Walker".</ref> a descendant of [[John Welsh of Ayr]] and [[John Knox]].<ref>{{cite book | last=Maclean | first=John, Jr. | title=History of the College of New Jersey: From Its Origin in 1746 to the Commencement of 1854 | publisher= [[J. B. Lippincott & Co.]] | location=Philadelphia | year = 1877 |isbn= | pages=Vol. 1, p384 | nopp=true }}</ref> This latter claim of Knox descent though ancient in origin is long disputed and without primary documentation.<ref>{{cite book | last=Waters |title =Witherspoon, Knox | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=INfJxmPj2_wC&pg=PA80 | accessdate = 2010-10-16 | publisher=The New England historical and genealogical register, Volume 64 | year=1910 }}</ref> He attended the [[Haddington, East Lothian|Haddington]] Grammar School, and obtained a [[Master of Arts (Scotland)|Master of Arts]] from the [[University of Edinburgh]] in 1739. He remained at the university to study divinity.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Witherspoon |url=http://www.ushistory.org/declaration/signers/witherspoon.htm |website=ushistory.org |publisher=Independence Hall Association |accessdate=17 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150607151155/http://www.ushistory.org/Declaration/signers/witherspoon.htm |archivedate= 7 June 2015 |df= }}</ref> In 1764, he was awarded an honorary doctorate degree in divinity by the [[University of St. Andrews]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tait|first1=L. Gordon|title=The Piety of John Witherspoon: Pew, Pulpit, and Public Forum|year=2001|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|isbn=0664501338|page=13}}</ref>
Witherspoon was a staunch Protestant, nationalist, and supporter of [[republicanism]]. Consequently, he was opposed to the [[Roman Catholic]] [[Legitimist]] [[Jacobite rising of 1745|Jacobite rising of 1745–46]]. Following the Jacobite victory at the [[Battle of Falkirk (1746)]], he was briefly imprisoned at [[Doune Castle]],<ref>{{cite web |publisher = The History of the Presbyterian Church |title = John Witherspoon |url = http://presbyterianhistory.com/b_witherspoon.htm |accessdate = 2007-12-30 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080220154431/http://presbyterianhistory.com/b_witherspoon.htm |archivedate = February 20, 2008}}</ref> which had a long-term effect on his health.
He became a [[Church of Scotland]] ([[Presbyterian]]) minister at [[Beith]], [[Ayrshire]] (1745–1758), where he married Elizabeth Montgomery of Craighouse. They had ten children, with five surviving to adulthood.
From 1758 to 1768, he was minister of the [[Laigh kirk, Paisley]] (Low Kirk). Witherspoon became prominent within the Church as an Evangelical opponent of the [[Moderate Party (Scotland)|Moderate Party]].<ref>{{cite book |last = Herman |first=Arthur |title=The Scottish Enlightenment |publisher=Fourth Estate |year =2003 |ISBN = 1-84115-276-5 |page=186}}</ref> During his two pastorates he wrote three well-known works on [[theology]], notably the satire "Ecclesiastical Characteristics" (1753), which opposed the philosophical influence of [[Francis Hutcheson (philosopher)|Francis Hutcheson]].<ref>{{cite book |last = Macintyre |first = Alasdair |title=Whose Justice? Which Rationality? |publisher=Duckworth |year =1988 |ISBN = 0-7156-2199-8 |page=244}}</ref>
== Princeton == [[File:Maclean house.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The [[President's House (Princeton)|President's House]] in Princeton, New Jersey. Completed in 1756, John Witherspoon lived here from 1768 to 1779; it is a U.S. [[National Historic Landmark]].]] At the urging of [[Benjamin Rush]] and [[Richard Stockton (1730–1781)|Richard Stockton]], whom he met in [[Paisley, Renfrewshire|Paisley]],<ref>Rampant Scotland [http://www.rampantscotland.com/famous/blfamwitherspoon.htm "Rampant Scotland, John Witherspoon"]</ref> Witherspoon finally accepted their renewed invitation (having turned one down in 1766) to become president and head professor of the small Presbyterian [[Princeton University|College of New Jersey]] in Princeton.<ref>Rush and Stockton's recruiting letters can be found in Butterfield, L. H., "John Witherspoon Comes to America", Princeton University Library, Princeton, New Jersey. 1953</ref> Thus, Witherspoon and his family emigrated to [[New Jersey]] in 1768.
At the age of 45, he became the sixth president of the college, later known as [[Princeton University]]. Upon his arrival, Witherspoon found the school in debt, with weak instruction, and a library collection which clearly failed to meet student needs. He immediately began fund-raising—locally and back home in Scotland—added three hundred of his own books to the library, and began purchasing scientific equipment including the [[Rittenhouse orrery]], many maps, and a terrestrial [[globe]].
Witherspoon also instituted a number of reforms, including modeling the [[syllabus]] and university structure after that used at the [[University of Edinburgh]] and other [[Scottish universities]]. He also firmed up entrance requirements, which helped the school compete with [[Harvard]] and [[Yale]] for scholars.
Witherspoon personally taught courses in eloquence or belles lettres, chronology (history), and divinity. However, none was more important than [[moral philosophy]] (a required course). An advocate of [[natural law]] within a [[Christian]] and republican [[cosmology]], Witherspoon considered moral philosophy vital for ministers, lawyers, and those holding positions in government ([[magistrate]]s). Firm but good-humored in his leadership, Witherspoon was very popular among both faculty and students.
Witherspoon had been a prominent evangelical Presbyterian minister in Scotland before accepting the Princeton position. As the college's primary occupation at the time was training ministers, Witherspoon became a major leader of the early [[Presbyterian Church]] in America. He also helped organize [[Nassau Presbyterian Church]] in Princeton, New Jersey.
Nonetheless, Witherspoon transformed a college designed predominantly to train clergymen into a school that would equip the leaders of a new Protestant country. Students who later played prominent roles in the new nation's development included [[James Madison]], [[Aaron Burr]], [[Philip Freneau]], [[William Bradford (Attorney General)|William Bradford]], and [[Hugh Henry Brackenridge]].<ref>Jeffry H. Morrison, ''John Witherspoon and the Founding of the American Republic'' (2005)</ref> From among his students came 37 judges (three of whom became justices of the [[U.S. Supreme Court]]); 10 Cabinet officers; 12 members of the Continental Congress, 28 U.S. senators, and 49 United States congressmen.
In 1774, Witherspoon wrote of an encounter with an unexplained atmospheric phenomenon. Witherspoon and a few aides were walking along [[Lake Carnegie (New Jersey)|Lake Carnegie]], when an "orb of fire" descended and made its way over to the group. Witherspoon wrote in his journal that it was a visit from an angel, who informed him that he, too, was a divine emissary.<ref>{{cite book |last=Pyne |first=F. W. |title=Descendants of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence |location=Rockport, Maine |publisher=Picton press |volume=4 Pt. 4 |page=204 |edition=2nd }}</ref>
== Revolutionary War == [[File:Declaration of Independence (1819), by John Trumbull.jpg|thumb|left|300px|In [[John Trumbull]]'s famous painting, Witherspoon is the second seated figure from the (viewer's) right among those shown in the background facing the large table.<ref>[http://www.americanrevolution.org/deckey.html americanrevolution.org] Key to Trumbull's picture</ref>]] Long wary of the power of the [[British Crown]], Witherspoon saw the growing centralization of government, progressive ideology of colonial authorities, and establishment of [[Episcopacy]] authority as a threat to the Liberties of the colonies. Of particular interest to Witherspoon was the crown's growing interference in the local and colonial affairs which previously had been the prerogatives and rights of the American authorities. When the crown began to give additional authority to its appointed Episcopacy over Church affairs, British authorities hit a nerve in the Presbyterian Scot, who saw such events in the same lens as his Scottish [[Covenanter]]s. Soon, Witherspoon came to support the [[American Revolution|Revolution]], joining the [[Committee of Correspondence]] and Safety in early 1774. His 1776 sermon "The Dominion of Providence over the Passions of Men" was published in many editions and he was elected to the [[Continental Congress]] as part of the [[New Jersey]] delegation,<ref>{{cite book| last =Herman| first=Arthur|title=The Scottish Enlightenment | publisher=Fourth Estate| year =2003|isbn=1-84115-276-5|page=237}}</ref> appointed Congressional Chaplain by the President of the Continental Congress [[John Hancock]], and in July 1776, voted to adopt the [[Lee Resolution|Virginia Resolution for Independence]]. In answer to an objection that the country was not yet ready for [[independence]], according to tradition he replied that it "was not only ripe for the measure, but in danger of rotting for the want of it." He lost a son during the [[Battle of Dutchtown]] in 1777.
Witherspoon served in Congress from June 1777 until November 1784 and became one of its most influential members and a workhorse of indigenous energy. He served on over 10,000 committees, most notably the sitting committees, the board of peace and the committee on public correspondence or common affairs. He spoke often in concurrence; helped draft the [[Articles of Confederation]]; helped organize the executive departments; played a major role in shaping public policy; and drew up the instructions for the peace commissioners. He fought against the flood of paper money, and opposed the issuance of bonds without provision for their amortization. "No business can be done, some say, because money is scarce", he wrote. He also served twice in the [[New Jersey Legislature]], and strongly supported the adoption of the [[United States Constitution]] during the New Jersey ratification debates.
In November 1777, American forces neared, Witherspoon closed and evacuated the College of New Jersey. The main building, [[Nassau Hall]], was badly damaged and his papers and personal notes were lost. Witherspoon was responsible for its reconstruction after the war, which caused him great personal and financial difficulty. In 1780 he was elected to a one-year term in the [[New Jersey Legislative Council]] representing [[Somerset County, New Jersey|Somerset County]]. At the age of 68, he married a 24-year-old widow, with whom he had two more children.<ref>{{Cite web|url= [https://etcweb.princeton.edu/CampusWWW/Companion/witherspoon_john.html] |accessdate= 2018-10-07}}</ref>
== Death and burial == Witherspoon suffered eye injuries and was blind by 1792. He died in 1794 on his farm [[Tusculum (Princeton, New Jersey)|Tusculum]], just outside Princeton, and is buried along Presidents Row in [[Princeton Cemetery]].<ref>{{FAG|1156|John Knox Witherspoon}}</ref> An inventory of Witherspoon's possessions taken at his death included "two slaves ... valued at a hundred dollars each", indicating that he owned slaves during his life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://libguides.princeton.edu/c.php?g=84056&p=544524|title=LibGuides: African American Studies: Slavery at Princeton|last=Knowlton|first=Steven|website=libguides.princeton.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-09-15}}</ref>
== Family == Witherspoon and his wife, Elizabeth Montgomery, had a total of 10 children, only five of which survived to accompany their parents to America. James, the eldest, a young man of great promise, graduated from Princeton in 1770, and joined the American army as an aide to General [[Francis Nash]], with the rank of major. The next youngest son, John, graduated from Princeton in 1774, practiced medicine in South Carolina, and was lost at sea in 1795. David, the youngest son, graduated the same year as his brother, married General Francis Nash's widow, and practiced law in New Bern, North Carolina. Anna, the eldest daughter, married Reverend Samuel Smith on June 28, 1775. Reverend Samuel Smith succeeded Dr. Witherspoon as president of Princeton in 1775. Frances, the youngest daughter, married Dr. [[David Ramsay (historian)|David Ramsay]], a delegate from South Carolina to the continental Congress, on March 18, 1763. Witherspoon is an ancestor of actress [[Reese Witherspoon]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=MacLean|first1=Maggie|title=Elizabeth Montgomery Witherspoon|url=http://www.womenhistoryblog.com/2009/06/elizabeth-montgomery-witherspoon.html|website=History of American Women|publisher=History of American Women|accessdate=25 October 2016}}</ref>
== Philosophy == [[File:Witherspoon-paisley.jpg|thumb|250px|right|John Witherspoon Statue, Paisley, Scotland by [[Alexander Stoddart]]]] According to Herbert Hovenkamp, Witherspoon's most lasting contribution was the initiation of the [[Scottish School of Common Sense|Scottish Common-Sense Realism]], which he had learned by reading [[Thomas Reid]] and two of his expounders [[Dugald Stewart]] and [[James Beattie (writer)|James Beattie]].<ref name=hovenkamp>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ObgnAAAAYAAJ&q=Science+and+Religion+in+America&dq=Science+and+Religion+in+America&pgis=1 Science and Religion in America, 1800–1860], Herbert Hovenkamp, University of Pennsylvania Press, 1978 {{ISBN|0-8122-7748-1}} pp. 5, 9</ref> <!-- also quoted on page 5 Of HovenKamp -->
Witherspoon revised the moral philosophy curriculum, strengthened the college's commitment to natural philosophy, and positioned Princeton in the larger transatlantic world of the republic of letters. Although he was a proponent of Christian values, Witherspoon's common sense approach to the [[public morality]] of civil magistrates was more influenced by the Enlightenment ethics of Scottish philosophers [[Francis Hutcheson (philosopher)|Francis Hutcheson]] and [[Thomas Reid]] than the Christian idealism of [[Jonathan Edwards (theologian)|Jonathan Edwards]]. In regard to civil magistrates, Witherspoon thus believed moral judgment should be pursued as a science. He held to old concepts from the [[Roman Republic]] of virtuous leadership by civil magistrates, but he also regularly recommended that his students read such modern philosophers as [[Machiavelli]], [[Montesquieu]], and [[David Hume]], even though he disapproved of Hume's "infidel" stance on religion.
Virtue, he argued, could be deduced through the development of the moral sense, an ethical compass instilled by God in all human beings and developed through religious education (Reid) or civil sociability (Hutcheson). Witherspoon saw morality as having two distinct components: [[spirituality|spiritual]] and [[wikt:temporal#Adjective|temporal]]. Civil government owed more to the latter than the former in Witherspoon's Presbyterian doctrine. Thus, public morality owed more to the natural moral laws of the Enlightenment than to revealed Christianity.
In his lectures on moral philosophy at Princeton, required of all juniors and seniors, Witherspoon argued for the revolutionary right of resistance and recommended checks and balances within government. He made a profound impression on his student James Madison, whose suggestions for the [[United States Constitution]] followed both Witherspoon's and Hume's ideas. The historian [[Douglass Adair]] writes, "The syllabus of Witherspoon's lectures . . . explains the conversion of the young Virginian to the philosophy of [[the Enlightenment]]."<ref>Adair, "James Madison", Fame and the Founding Fathers, ed. Trevor Colbourn (ndianapolis: Liberty Fund, 1974) 181.</ref>
Witherspoon accepted the impossibility of maintaining public morality or virtue in the citizenry without an effective religion. In this sense, the temporal principles of morality required a religious component which derived its authority from the spiritual. Therefore, public religion was a vital necessity in maintaining the public morals. However, in this framework, non-Christian societies could have virtue, which, by his definition, could be found in natural law. Witherspoon, in accordance with the Scottish moral sense philosophy, taught that all human beings, Christian or otherwise, could be virtuous, but he was nonetheless committed to Christianity as the only route to personal salvation.

'''Joshua M. Ferguson''' is a filmmaker and campaigner for trans rights.<ref name=globeandmail>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-born-filmmaker-receives-non-binary-birth-certificate-after/|title=Ontario-born filmmaker receives non-binary birth certificate after legal battle with province|publisher=|via=The Globe and Mail}}</ref>
In May 2017, Ferguson applied to change their birth registration to non-binary. After extended delay, in September 2017 they filed a human rights complaint with the Human Rights Tribunal of Ontario. The government of Ontario changed its policies in 2018 and issued Ferguson with a birth certificate showing their gender as non-binary.<ref name=globeandmail/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/gender-x-ontario-issues-its-first-ever-non-binary-birth-n872676 |title=Gender 'X': Ontario issues its first 'nonbinary' birth certificate |publisher=Nbcnews.com |date= |accessdate=2018-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Leyland Cecco in Toronto |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/may/07/ontario-non-binary-birth-certificate-canada-transgender |title=Transgender rights: Ontario issues first non-binary birth certificate | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2018-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/canada/filmmaker-receives-non-binary-birth-certificate-that-correctly-display-who-i-am-after-legal-battle-with-ontario |title=Filmmaker receives non-binary birth certificate ‘that correctly display who I am’ after legal battle with Ontario |publisher=National Post |date=2018-05-08 |accessdate=2018-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.ca/joshua-m-ferguson/ill-keep-fighting-until-im-legally-recognized-as-a-non-binary-canadian_a_23255775/ |title=I'll Keep Fighting Until I'm Legally Recognized As A Non-Binary Canadian |publisher=Huffingtonpost.ca |date=2017-10-25 |accessdate=2018-06-05}}</ref> As a consequence of Ferguson's case, in addition to having options to change gender to male, female or X, Ontario is the first Canadian province, or government administration in the world, to permit citizens to request birth certificates with no sexual designation.<ref>https://www.ontario.ca/page/changing-your-sex-designation-your-birth-registration-and-birth-certificate</ref>
Ferguson's documentary about their life as a non-binary person and the fight for legal recognition is in post-production.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_ca/article/wj7w9q/this-person-just-received-ontarios-first-non-binary-birth-certificate |title=This Person Just Received Ontario's First Non-Binary Birth Certificate |publisher=VICE |date=2018-05-07 |accessdate=2018-06-05}}</ref> Their film ''Whispers of Life'' was winner of the audience award and jury award for Best GLBTTQ* Short Film in the 2014 [[Reel Pride]] Film Festival and won the audience award in the Reelout Queer Film + Video Festival.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.reelout.com/2014/02/2014-reelout-audience-awards-announced/|title=2014 Reelout Audience Awards Announced|date=2014-02-13|work=Reelout|access-date=2018-06-05|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2862782/|title=Whispers of Life|date=21 September 2013|publisher=|via=www.imdb.com}}</ref> Ferguson is the director and producer of "Limina", released in 2016 the film features the experience of a gender-fluid child. "Limina" was the first film to be nominated in both male and female performance categories for the same actor in the [[Leo Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/gender-fluid-actor-judged-eligible-male-female-categories-at-canadian-awards-show-969289 |title=Gender-Fluid Actor Judged Eligible in Both Male and Female Categories at Canadian Awards Show |publisher=Hollywood Reporter |date=2017-01-27 |accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://theatrefilm.ubc.ca/film-studies-m-a-alumnx-joshua-m-fergusons-film-limina-makes-history/ |title=Film Studies M.A. Alumnx Joshua M. Ferguson’s Film Limina Makes History |publisher=Theatrefilm.ubc.ca |date= |accessdate=2018-06-06}}</ref>

{{Infobox Christian leader | honorific-prefix = [[The Most Reverend]] | name = José Telésforo Paúl y Vargas, [[Society of Jesus|SJ]] | title = Archbishop of Santafé en Nueva Granada | image = A.josetelesforo paul.jpg | image_size = 250 | church = [[Catholic Church]] | archdiocese = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bogotá|Santafé en Nueva Granada]] | province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bogotá|Santafé en Nueva Granada]] | appointed = 6 August 1884 | term_start = 14 November 1884 | term_end = 8 April 1889 | predecessor = [[Vicente Arbeláez Gómez]] | successor = [[Ignacio León Velasco]], [[Society of Jesus|SJ]] | ordination = 5 December 1855 | consecration = 25 March 1876 | consecrated_by = [[Ignacio Antonio Parra]] | birth_date = 5 January 1831 | birth_place = [[Bogotá]], [[Colombia]] | death_date = 8 April 1889 (aged 58) | death_place = [[La Mesa, Cundinamarca|La Mesa]], [[Cundinamarca Department|Cundinamarca]], [[Colombia]] | previous_post = Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Panamá|Panamá]] <small>(1876–1884)</small> | alma_mater = [[Del Rosario University]] }}{{Spanish name|Paúl|Vargas}} '''José Telésforo''' '''Paúl y Vargas''', [[Society of Jesus|SJ]] (5 January 1831 – 8 April 1889) was a [[Colombia]]n [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] [[Bishop (Catholic)|bishop]] and [[Jesuit]] who worked in [[Panama]] and Colombia. Born in [[Bogotá]], he served as bishop of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Panamá|Panamá]] from 1876 to 1884 and as archbishop of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bogotá|Santafé en Nueva Granada]] (now the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bogotá|Archdiocese of Bogotá]], Colombia) from 1884 until his death in 1889.
== Biography ==
=== Early life and education === José Telésforo Paúl y Vargas was born on 5 January 1831 in [[Bogotá]], [[Colombia]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bvarj.html|title=Archbishop José Telésphor Paúl y Vargas [Catholic-Hierarchy]|last=Cheney|first=David M.|website=www.catholic-hierarchy.org|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/bogo0.htm#12639|title=Archdiocese of Bogotá, Colombia|newspaper=GCatholic|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Jose-Telesforo-de-Paul-y-Vargas-Arzobispo/4692692124440089340|title=Jose Telesforo de Paul y Vargas, Arzobispo|website=geni_family_tree|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref> The son of Rafael Paúl y Motta, a Venezuelan lawyer, and Florentina Vargas Gaitán, he had two siblings, Felpie Fermín and Rafaela.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.enciclopedicohistcultiglesiaal.org/diccionario/index.php/PA%C3%9AL,_Jos%C3%A9_Tel%C3%A9sforo|title=PAÚL, José Telésforo - Diccionario de Historia Cultural de América Latina|website=www.enciclopedicohistcultiglesiaal.org|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref>
After studying at the [[Del Rosario University|Colegio Mayor de Nuestra Señora del Rosario]], Paúl entered the [[Society of Jesus]] at age 13 at their house in [[Popayán]].<ref name=":3" /> In 1850, already a teacher at the [[Colegio Mayor de San Bartolomé]] in Bogotá, he went into exile with other Jesuits due to the Society's persecution by General [[Hilario Lopez (general)|Hilario Lopez]].<ref name=":3" /> After leaving Bogotá, he traveled to Europe, where he continued his studies in [[Belgium]], [[France]], and [[Azpeitia|Loyola]], [[Spain]].<ref name=":3" /> Through his education, he became a notable [[Christian humanism|Christian humanist]] and [[Polyglotism|polyglot]], speaking and writing in four or five languages fluently.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://babel.banrepcultural.org/cdm/singleitem/collection/p17054coll10/id/44|title=Oración fúnebre del señor José Telésforo Paul, Arzobispo de Bogotá :: Obras generales|website=babel.banrepcultural.org|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref>
=== Priesthood === Paúl was ordained a priest on 5 December 1855,<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> and was assigned to the [[Seminario de Guatemala]] in [[Guatemala City]], where he taught [[rhetoric]] and the [[humanities]].<ref name=":3" /> When the anti-Jesuit persecution ended in Colombia in 1858, his superiors sent him back to Bogotá, where he rose to prominence as a teacher, [[orator]], and counselor.<ref name=":3" /> In 1861, he was exiled from Colombia for the second time, this time by President [[Tomás Cipriano de Mosquera]].<ref name=":3" /> He returned to Guatemala, where he was a professor of theology at the seminary and was also mastor of novices for the Guatemalan Jesuits.<ref name=":3" /> In 1869, he was sent with the Rev. Roberto Pozo to found a new Jesuit residence in [[San Salvador]], but were expelled in 1872 by Salvadoran President [[Santiago González (politician)|Santiago González]], along with other religious orders.<ref name=":3" />
Paúl and the other Jesuits moved to [[Ecuador]], before being invited to [[Panama State]] (at that time an autonomous province of Colombia) by President [[Buenaventura Correoso]].<ref name=":3" /> He taught there at the diocesan seminary and later was superior of the Jesuits in Panama, with his seat at the Church of St. Francis in [[Panama City]].<ref name=":3" />
=== Bishop of Panama === On 17 September 1875, Paúl was appointed Bishop of Panamá by [[Pope Pius IX]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" /> He succeeded [[Ignacio Antonio Parra]], who consecrated him bishop on 25 March 1876, making Paúl the first bishop consecrated in [[Panama]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" />
As bishop of Panamá, Paúl reorganized and established parishes, made frequent pastoral visits to different communities, and made efforts to improve the discipline and education of the clergy.<ref name=":3" /> He also took special interest in the construction of the [[Panama Canal]], construction of which began in 1881 by [[France]].<ref name=":3" /> Paúl became friends with [[Ferdinand de Lesseps]], the French diplomat in charge of the project, and blessed the work at the start of construction.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Uo8tE1_KMTQC&pg=PT1062&lpg=PT1062&dq=Jos%C3%A9+Tel%C3%A9sforo+Paul&source=bl&ots=tfZq55ia2C&sig=C5HSXGCc8VEIk3xE_wfKFJZ_Agg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_p4jx96PRAhUK7SYKHb-xArwQ6AEIXTAO#v=onepage&q=Jos%C3%A9%20Tel%C3%A9sforo%20Paul&f=false|title=David McCullough Great Moments in History E-book Box Set: 1776, The Johnstown Flood, Path Between the Seas, The Great Bridge, The Course of Human Events|last=McCullough|first=David|date=2011-05-24|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781451658231|language=en}}</ref> He eventually became a trusted advisor and counselor of Lesseps, who described Paúl as "the most illustrious prelate I have ever met."<ref name=":3" /> In addition, he paid special attention to providing religious care to residents of the [[Panama Canal Zone]], dividing it into three different districts and ensuring the regular visit of Panamanian priests.<ref name=":3" />
Paúl made pastoral visits through the diocese several times, and worked to establish schools and hospitals, and invited the [[Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul|Daughters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul]] to staff many of them.<ref name=":3" /> He wrote [[pastoral letter]]s, which encouraged [[evangelism]] and Catholic education, condemned the conflict of [[liberalism]] with Catholicism, and addressed the relationship between church and state.<ref name=":3" /> In 1877, Paúl personally had traveled to the [[Congress of Colombia]] to demand respectful treatment of the church by the government.<ref name=":3" />
=== Archbishop of Bogotá === Following the death of Archbishop [[Vicente Arbeláez Gómez]], Paúl was appointed archbishop of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bogotá|Santafé en Nueva Granada]] (now Bogotá) on 6 August 1884 by [[Pope Leo XIII]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> There, he participated in the drafting of the new [[Colombian Constitution of 1886]].<ref name=":3" /> He died on 8 April 1889 in Bogotá, aged 58.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
== Episcopal lineage == * Cardinal [[Scipione Rebiba]] * Cardinal [[Giulio Antonio Santorio]] (1566) * Cardinal [[Girolamo Bernerio]], [[Dominican Order|OP]] (1586) * Archbishop [[Galeazzo Sanvitale]] (1604) * Cardinal [[Ludovico Ludovisi]] (1621) * Cardinal [[Luigi Caetani]] (1622) * Cardinal [[Ulderico Carpegna]] (1630) * Cardinal [[Paluzzo Paluzzi Altieri degli Albertoni]] (1666) * [[Pope Benedict XIII]] (1675) * [[Pope Benedict XIV]] (1724) * Archbishop [[Enrico Enríquez]] (1743) * Bishop [[Manuel Quintano Bonifaz]] (1749) * Cardinal [[Francisco Antonio de Lorenzana]] (1765) * Bishop [[Atanasio Puyal y Poveda]] (1790) * Bishop [[Andrés Esteban y Gómez]] (1815) * Bishop [[Salvador Jiménez y Padilla]] (1816) * Bishop [[Jose Antonio Chaves (bishop)|Jose Antonio Chaves]], [[Order of Friars Minor|OFM]] (1834) * Bishop [[Bernabé Rojas]], [[Dominican Order|OP]] (1855) * Bishop [[Domingo Antonio Riaño Martínez]] (1855) * Archbishop [[Antonio Herrán y Zaldúa]] (1855) * Archbishop [[Vicente Arbeláez Gómez]] (1860) * Bishop [[Ignacio Antonio Parra]] (1871) * Archbishop '''José Telésforo Paúl y Vargas''', [[Society of Jesus|SJ]] (1876)
