{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox Politician | name = Steve Fielding | honorific-suffix = | image = | imagesize = 150 | caption = | office = [[Australian Senate|Senator]] for [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | term_start = 1 July 2005 | term_end = 30 June 2011 | predecessor = | successor = | constituency = | majority = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1960|10|17}} | birth_place = [[Melbourne]], Victoria, Australia | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Australian | party = [[Family First Party]] | spouse = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[RMIT University]]
[[Monash University]] | occupation = | profession = Engineer | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} {{about|the former senator|the academic|Steven Fielding (political historian)}} '''Steven Fielding''' (born 17 October 1960) is a former Australian [[Australian Senate|senator]] for the state of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and the former federal [[parliamentary leader]] of the [[Family First Party]]. He was elected to the upper house at the [[Australian federal election, 2004|2004 federal election]] on two per cent of the [[first-preference votes]]. He failed to gain re-election at the [[Australian federal election, 2010|2010 federal election]]. His term ended on 30 June 2011.[http://www.theage.com.au/national/family-firsts-steve-fielding-loses-senate-seat-20100916-15ebv.html Family First's Steve Fielding loses Senate seat: The Age 16 September 2010]{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/federal-election/ballarat-blacksmith-forges-ahead-with-nod-to-dlp-heroes-20100822-13axy.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=Ballarat blacksmith forges ahead with nod to DLP heroes | first=Barney | last=Zwartz | date=23 August 2010}}[http://www.abc.net.au/elections/federal/2010/guide/senate-results.htm 2010 Senate Results – Summary: ABC elections] == Early life == Fielding was born on 17 October 1960, in [[Melbourne]], where he was raised in the suburb of [[Reservoir, Victoria|Reservoir]]. His parents, Shirley and George Fielding, had a large family consisting of 16 children, and Fielding spent much of his childhood sharing a bedroom with five brothers in the family's three-bedroom home.{{cite news | last = Cadzow | first = Jane | date = 8 October 2005 | title = Meet the Fieldings | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | location = Sydney, Australia | page = 20 }} His early education was at the local Keon Park Primary School, He later attended the nearby [[Merrilands High School]].{{cite web | year = 2009 | title = About Steve | work = Senator Steve Fielding | url = http://www.stevefielding.com.au/about/ | accessdate = 29 November 2009 }} Academically, Fielding suffered setbacks through an undiagnosed case of [[dyslexia]], and this led to problems studying subjects such as English.{{cite news | last = Riley | first = Robyn | date = 27 September 2009 | title = Time to get 'fiskal' – Funding calls on dyslexia | work = [[Herald Sun]] | location = Melbourne, Australia | page = 102 }} His dyslexia was only diagnosed after he revealed his learning difficulties in 2009, and he was diagnosed as suffering from both [[Apraxia#Apraxia of speech|developmental apraxia of speech]] and [[Augmentative and alternative communication#Developmental dyspraxia|developmental surface dyspraxia]], along with the dyslexia. Nevertheless, he excelled in mathematics, and his high marks in this subject allowed him to graduate with sufficiently high scores to gain entry into the [[Bachelor of Engineering]] degree at [[RMIT University|Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology]] (RMIT), where he studied [[electronic engineering]].{{cite news | last = Fielding | first = Steve | date = 13 September 2009 | title = A learning disability doesn't have to limit who you are | work = [[The Age|The Sunday Age]] | location = Melbourne, Australia | page = 19 }} Upon graduating in 1983, Fielding accepted a position at [[Hewlett-Packard]], and later he moved into management at technology firms [[NEC]] and [[Siemens]]. Fielding returned to university to undertake a [[Master of Business Administration]] (MBA) at [[Monash University]], completing it in 1992. He later moved to [[Wellington]], New Zealand, where he worked for [[Telecom New Zealand]] in "change management" during a difficult time for the industry, as it was undergoing [[deregulation]].{{cite news | last = Bachelard | first = Michael | date = 6 November 2004 | title = Not a hellfire and brimstone man | work = [[The Australian|The Weekend Australian]] | location = Sydney, Australia | page = 21 }} He returned to Australia three years later, in 1995, and worked for [[United Energy]], the Australian [[Yellow Pages]] and as a [[marketing manager]] at [[Vision Super]]. Fielding entered politics in 2003 when he successfully stood as an independent candidate for the [[Knox City Council]]. He has described the decision to stand as "very last-minute", but others, such as the mayor of the council, Jenny Moore, and then Victorian [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Peter Lockwood]], said Fielding was very open about his intent to move into federal politics. Either way, both Lockwood and Labor MP [[Bob Stensholt]] have described how Fielding later made inquiries about the possibility of running for one of the major parties before joining Family First. ==2004 election== Fielding was elected to represent Victoria in the Senate at the [[Australian federal election, 2004|2004 federal election]]. He was the first representative of Family First to be elected to the [[Parliament of Australia|Federal Parliament]].{{cite news | last = Green | first = Jonathan | date = 10 August 2005 | title = Tears and cheers at Family First man's debut | work = [[The Age]] | location = Melbourne, Australia | page = 1 }} Fielding's election was not expected – Family First had only been founded two years before the election, and it was not expected to succeed in its first federal election in Victoria. Like many senators, Fielding gained a quota under the Senate's [[proportional representation]] system by receiving preferences from other parties (see [[Australian electoral system]]). The [[Australian Democrats]] and the [[Australian Labor Party]] agreed to swap preferences with Family First. But Fielding benefited from the larger-than-expected surplus of [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] preferences, and stayed in the count long enough to receive Democrat and Labor preferences, defeating the [[Australian Greens]]' candidate [[David Risstrom]] for the last Senate place in Victoria.{{cite news | last = Green | first = Anthony | title = Final Victoria Senate Results | work = Australia Votes: Federal Election | date=9 October 2004 | publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | url = http://www.abc.net.au/elections/federal/2004/results/sendVIC.htm | accessdate = 26 November 2009 }} As a result, Fielding was elected although his party as a whole received just 56,376 votes (1.9%) for the Senate in Victoria.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/fielding-first-one-man-one-vote-and-a-whole-lot-of-power-20080927-4pdz.html?deviceType=text|title=Fielding first: one man, one vote ... and a whole lot of power|last=Gordon|first=Josh|date=28 September 2008|work=[[The Age|The Sunday Age]]|location=Melbourne, Australia|page=14|access-date=|via=}} When first elected, the [[Howard Government]] held a slim majority in the Senate, sufficient that Fielding would only hold the balance of power if one of the government senators chose to [[Crossing the floor|cross the floor]]. This changed after the 2007 federal election (the changes of which took effect in 2008), when the balance of power in the Senate shifted to a combination of Fielding, the five Australian Greens senators and independent [[Nick Xenophon]]. ==Federal politics== While Family First is generally regarded as a [[Conservatism|conservative]] party, Fielding stated he would not be an automatic supporter of the then [[Coalition (Australia)|Coalition]] opposition in the Senate. On some issues which he saw as affecting the wellbeing of families, such as the [[WorkChoices]] industrial relations policies, he indicated disagreement with government policies. In February 2009, he told a Senate hearing that he believed divorce added to the impact of [[global warming]] because it resulted in people switching to a "resource-inefficient lifestyle".{{cite news | title=Divorce adds to the impact of global warming – Steve Fielding | date=25 February 2009 | work =The Daily Telegraph |location=Australia | url =http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/money/story/0,26860,25102743-5015795,00.html | accessdate = 25 February 2009 }} ===Balance of power=== With some [[backbenchers]] being willing to [[cross the floor]], Fielding's vote was important on some of the Howard government's more controversial legislation. His vote ensured the passage of [[Voluntary student unionism]],[http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Graffiti-attack-on-Family-First-office/2005/12/10/1134086840993.html Graffiti Attack on Steve Fielding's Office After VSU Vote], ''The Age'', 10 December 2005 the overturning of [[civil unions]] legislation in the [[Australian Capital Territory]],[http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2006/s1664191.htm Bid to save ACT civil unions fails], ''PM'', 15 June 2006 and changes to media ownership laws.[http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2006/s1763643.htm Media laws pass the Senate], ''PM'', 12 October 2006 Conversely, his intention to vote "no" ensured the defeat of the Howard government's proposed tightening of asylum seeker laws.[http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2006/s1714861.htm Backbench rebellion forces border protection backdown], ''Lateline'', 14 August 2006 ===Climate change=== In mid-2009, Fielding flew to the US on a self-funded trip to discover more about climate change. He came back unconvinced that man-made carbon dioxide emissions were the main driver of climate change. He subsequently voted against the Rudd Government's Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme. Fielding also attended the Copenhagen Climate Conference in December 2009.{{cite web|last=Kippist |first=Lucy |url=http://www.thepunch.com.au/articles/the-real-reason-ill-fight-in-the-senate-on-climate-change/ |title=The real reason I'll fight in the Senate on climate change | Article |publisher=The Punch |accessdate=2 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614010838/http://www.thepunch.com.au/articles/the-real-reason-ill-fight-in-the-senate-on-climate-change/ |archivedate=14 June 2010 }} ===Youth allowance=== In 2009 Fielding teamed up with the coalition to defeat the government's proposed changes to the youth allowance system. He said the changes were unfair to rural and regional students and that it would leave 26,000 students worse off.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/11/25/2752552.htm |title=Senate blocks youth allowance changes – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=25 November 2009 |accessdate=2 August 2010}} ===Alcohol=== Fielding opposed the Rudd Government's alcopops tax. He argued that taxing ready to drink alcohol beverages wouldn't put an end to binge drinking. He campaigned for the government to act against the practice.{{cite web|last=Kippist |first=Lucy |url=http://www.thepunch.com.au/articles/drunk-nation1/ |title=Our drunk nation | Article |publisher=The Punch |accessdate=2 August 2010}} ===Stimulus package=== Following the global financial crisis the Rudd Government passed an economic stimulus package with the help of Family First. As part of the deal Fielding secured a $200 million jobs fund called 'Get Communities Working'.{{cite web |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/senate/Committee/fapa_ctte/stimulus_package/report/d03.htm |title=Parliament of Australia:Senate:Committees:Finance and Public Administration Committee:Nation Building and Jobs Plan – Inquiry into the provisions of the Appropriation (Nation Building and Jobs) Bill (No. 1) 2008–2009 and 5 related bills – $PageTitle$ |publisher=Aph.gov.au |date=12 February 2009 |accessdate=2 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100809042448/http://www.aph.gov.au/senate/Committee/fapa_ctte/stimulus_package/report/d03.htm |archivedate=9 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }} ===Voluntary Student Unionism=== At the end of his campaign in support of the Howard government's Voluntary Student Unionism legislation, which was passed, the walls of Fielding's office were vandalised with pro-union graffiti. ===Luxury car tax=== An increase to the luxury car tax was defeated in the Senate on 4 September 2008, with Fielding joining the [[Coalition (Australia)|coalition]] in blocking the budget legislation. It was passed after Fielding negotiated exemptions for farmers and tourism operators.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/09/17/2367134.htm http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/09/17/2367134.htm], [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] news, 17 September 2008 ===Considered changing parties=== In early 2008, Fielding reportedly considered breaking away from Family First to establish a new political party, inviting [[Tim Costello]] and other "big names" to join him.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24423234-661,00.html |title=Senator Steve Fielding wanted to quit |author=Ben Packham and Peter Jean |work=[[Herald Sun]] |date=30 September 2008 |accessdate=11 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202045620/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24423234-661,00.html |archivedate=2 December 2008 }} The revelations came after Fielding changed his position on abortion, after being rebuffed by his party for taking a softer approach.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24408444-662,00.html |title=Family First Senator Steve Fielding retreats from abortion comments |author=Ben Packham |work=[[Herald Sun]] |date=27 September 2008 |accessdate=11 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090317070633/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,24408444-662,00.html |archivedate=17 March 2009 }} ===ISP level content filtering=== Fielding gave conditional support to the mandatory ISP level filtering scheme. A spokesperson for Family First indicated that the party would want X18+ rated and refused classification (RC) content banned for everyone, including adults.[http://www.theage.com.au/news/technology/biztech/net-filters-may-block-porn-and-fetish-sites/2008/10/27/1224955916155.html Net filters may block porn and gambling sites], ''The Age'', 27 October 2008. Fielding's support for [[Internet censorship in Australia]] was not reported on his official website. ===Same-sex marriage=== Fielding has compared same-sex marriages to incest:{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/fielding-likens-same-sex-marriage-to-incest-20091126-juo3.html |title=Fielding likens same-sex marriage to incest |work=The Age |accessdate=26 November 2009 | location=Melbourne | first=Misha | last=Schubert | date=27 November 2009}}
A bloke cannot marry his brother; it is not right. A woman cannot marry their sister; it is not right. A bloke cannot marry a bloke because it is not right, and a female cannot marry a female because it is not right. I don't support this.
===Paid Parental Leave Scheme=== In June 2010, during the Senate discussion on the proposed [[Parental leave|Paid Parental Leave Scheme]], Fielding suggested "some women may rort the scheme by deliberately falling pregnant and then having a late-term abortion". He was subsequently criticised by all sides of Australian politics for these comments.{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/06/17/2929288.htm |title=Fielding's abortion rorts claim 'offensive'|work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=17 June 2010 }} ===Legislation=== Fielding introduced the following legislation into Parliament:http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/download/legislation/billslst/billslst_c5cb7dfd-6ea5-42d2-bea7-a4c40e628ce8/upload_pdf/Bills%20List%202009.pdf;fileType=application%2Fpdf#search=%22family%20first%22{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *Protecting Problem Gamblers Bill 2009 *Keeping Jobs from Going Offshore (Protection of Personal Information) Bill 2009 *Britt Lapthorne Bill 2009 *Removing Branding from Cigarette Packs Bill 2009 *Keeping Banks Accountable Bill 2009 *Removal of Excessive Super Bill 2009 *Easy Comparison of Grocery Prices Bill 2008 *Poker Machine Harm Minimisation Bill 2008 *Poker Machine Harm Reduction Tax Bill 2008 *Alcohol Toll Reduction Bill 2007 *Restoring Family Work Balance Bill 2007 *Fair Bank and Credit Card Fees Bill 2007 *Predatory Pricing Bill 2007 *Creeping Acquisitions 2007 Bill ==Stunts== Fielding's use of publicity stunts was commented on by ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/why-steve-fielding-bothers/2008/09/25/1222217430711.html |title=Mr 2%: why Steve Fielding bothers: SMH 26/8/2008 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=25 September 2008 |accessdate=2 August 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/opinion/note-to-steve-forget-the-stunts/2008/09/06/1220121597553.html?page=fullpage |title=Note to Steve: forget the stunts: SMH 7/9/2008 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=7 September 2008 |accessdate=2 August 2010}} in May 2008, he joined protesting pensioners, who brought traffic to a standstill in the Melbourne CBD, when he and others took their shirts off in the style of the cab drivers who had successfully stripped for increased cab security, to demand $70- to $100-a-week rise in the pension.{{cite web|url=http://news.theage.com.au/world/ageing-aussies-strip-in-pension-protest-20080516-2ezb.html |title=Ageing Aussies strip in pension protest – Breaking News – World – Breaking News |work=The Age |date=16 May 2008 |accessdate=2 August 2010}}[http://www.livenews.com.au/Articles/2008/05/16/Pensioners_strip_during_pay_protest LIVENEWS.com.au > National > Pensioners strip during pay protest] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517174903/http://livenews.com.au/Articles/2008/05/16/Pensioners_strip_during_pay_protest |date=17 May 2008 }} Fielding also dressed as a giant beer bottle to promote Family First's proposed policy to introduce a [[Container deposit legislation|bottle return scheme]].{{Cite web | title = Steve Fielding dresses as beer bottle | publisher = ABC News | accessdate = 10 March 2011 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/photos/2008/03/13/2188321.htm }} ==Personal life== Fielding is a Christian and attends [[CityLife Church]], a large [[Pentecostal]] church in Melbourne.{{cite news | date = 23 July 2005 | title = Working for God | work = [[Herald Sun]] | location = Melbourne, Australia | page = W07 }} He rejects [[evolution]] and has publicly espoused his belief in [[Young Earth creationism]].[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xhhEeI3K7GU, ''ABC – Q&A '', 9 March 2010.] Fielding has three children. He has claimed he was sexually abused by a [[scoutmaster]] and family friend for two years when he was a teenager. No-one has been charged or prosecuted for the alleged offences.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/senator-reveals-he-was-sexually-abused-20091116-igs2.html |title=Senator reveals he was sexually abused |work=The Age |date= 16 November 2009|accessdate=2 August 2010 | location=Melbourne | first=Mex | last=Cooper}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/fieldings-abuse-claim-stuns-father-20091116-iia4.html |title=Fielding's abuse claim stuns father |work=The Age |date= 17 November 2009|accessdate=2 August 2010 | location=Melbourne | first=Ian | last=Munro}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{DEFAULTSORT:Fielding, Steve}} [[Category:Family First Party members of the Parliament of Australia]] [[Category:Members of the Australian Senate]] [[Category:Members of the Australian Senate for Victoria]] [[Category:Politicians from Melbourne]] [[Category:Australian monarchists]] [[Category:Australian Pentecostals]] [[Category:Christian Young Earth creationists]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:RMIT University alumni]] [[Category:People diagnosed with dyslexia]] [[Category:21st-century Australian politicians]]

{{Infobox monarch |name = Sweet Grass |title = [[Cree]] chief |birth_date = c. 1815 |death_date = on or shortly before January 11, 1877 |death_place = near [[Brosseau, Alberta]], Canada }}
'''Sweet Grass''' (also '''Sweetgrass''' or '''Wikaskokiseyin''' or '''Wihaskokiseyin''') ([[Circa|c.]]1815 – on or shortly before January 11, 1877) was a chief of the [[Cree]] in the 1860s and 1870s in western Canada. He worked with other chiefs and bands to participate in raids with enemy tribes. While a chief, Sweet Grass noticed the starvation and economic hardship the Cree were facing. This propelled him to work with the Canadian and eventually sign [[Treaty 6|Treaty Six]]. Sweet Grass believed that working alongside the government was one of the only solutions to the daily hardship the Cree were faced with. The Sweet Grass Reserve west of Battleford, Saskatchewan was named in his honor and is still functioning today.
==Life==
===Early life===
Sweet Grass or Wikaskokiseyin was born in a Cree Camp in the area near [[Fort Pitt Provincial Park|Fort Pitt, Saskatchewan]]. <ref>{{Cite book|title=Big Bear: The End of Freedom|last=Dempsey|first=Hugh|publisher=University of Regina Press|year=2006|isbn=|location=|page=43}}</ref> The exact date and place of his birth is unrecorded. His mother was kidnapped during a war with the Cree from a tribe, which was located around Missouri.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/wikaskokiseyin_abraham_10E.html|title=Biography – WIKASKOKISEYIN, ABRAHAM – Volume X (1871-1880) – Dictionary of Canadian Biography|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref> Due to this, Sweet Grass was not Cree and was Crow.<ref name=":15">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=7UBUF3X5QPQC|title=Big Bear: The End of Freedom|last=Dempsey|first=Hugh A.|date=2006|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889771963|location=|pages=29|language=en}}</ref> There is no record of his father. Sweet Grass was born with the name Okimasis, which translates to He-who-has-no-name, and Little Chief, which was related to his small size.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nuQ7W7x1MSwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Cuthand,+Doug.+Askiwina:+A+Cree+World.+Regina,+Saskatchewan:+Coteau+Books.+2007.#v=onepage&q=sweetgrass&f=false|title=Askiwina: A Cree World|last=Cuthand|first=Doug|date=2007-04-03|publisher=Coteau Books|isbn=9781550505054|location=|pages=42|language=en}}</ref> Warriors consistently taunted him due to his stature within the village.<ref name=":3" /> His name, “Sweet Grass” was inspired by an audacious feat that he attempted as a youth. He ventured into the Blackfoot territory, completely alone with the goal of capturing a heard of horses.<ref name=":2" /> Approaching the pasture, he hid in a bush and as a man advanced towards him, he took out his bow, killed and scalped him; proceeding to raid the pasture to return forty horses back to his tribe.<ref name=":3" /> His tribe was presented with a collection of grass dipped in the blood of the man he had killed.<ref name=":12"/> This was met with chants of “Sweet Grass”, which would eventually become his name as a Chief in 1870. Later that year, Sweet Grass converted to Roman Catholicism by Father Albert Lacombe and was baptized with the Christian name, Abraham.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/wikaskokiseyin_abraham_10E.html|title=Biography – WIKASKOKISEYIN, ABRAHAM – Volume X (1871-1880) – Dictionary of Canadian Biography|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref>
===Cree Childhood===
Due to the fact that Sweet Grass' Mother was captured by a Cree tribe, it is unknown if she partook in the established birthing and naming traditions. However, the Cree had a process to which they named their children. The father of the child would ask Cree Shamans with spiritual powers to help with the naming process.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=141|language=en}}</ref> The Shaman's decision would be based on a character or incident that they saw in their vision.<ref name=":4" /> Once a name was decided, the child was passed around the group where each individual blessed the child.<ref name=":4" /> This ceremony generally took place when the child reached the age of one.<ref name=":4" /> From this moment on, a special bond was formed between the child and whoever named them.<ref name=":4" /> There is no record of whether Sweet Grass and his mother took part in this ceremony. However, this likely happened because he was born in a Cree Camp. Children typically lived a carefree and adventurous childhood.<ref name=":5"/> Children did not wear much clothing and boys wore nothing until the age of five.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|language=en}}</ref> Children did not spend much time with their parents growing up, rather with their grandparents.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=143|language=en}}</ref> Sweet Grass’ childhood most likely went against this Cree norm because of his Mother’s capture. Young men would attach themselves to a hunter or warrior that they admired and followed or shadowed them in performing tasks.<ref name=":5" /> Sweet Grass most likely did not partake in this tradition or many other childhood ones. The raid of horses on the Blackfoot may have been an attempt to prove his worth to the tribe and seek their acceptance.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=7UBUF3X5QPQC|title=Big Bear: The End of Freedom|last=Dempsey|first=Hugh A.|date=2006|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889771963|location=|pages=43|language=en}}</ref>
===The Cree===
The Cree were located in the plains of Canada.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=7|language=en}}</ref> The Cree are divided into several different tribes in Saskatchewan and Alberta.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=9|language=en}}</ref> The name Cree represents a general ethnic group, however, there are several different tribes based on region and dialect. When Sweet Grass was chief, the different bands of the Cree were loose in a wide-ranging areas and usually named for the territory in which they operated<ref name=" Mandelbaum 1940 105">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=105|language=en}}</ref> It was not uncommon for different bands to hunt and perform rituals together as seen with Sweet Grass’ relationship with [[Big Bear]]. Families had the ability to break away from their current band and join another elsewhere.<ref name=" Mandelbaum 1940 105"/> Cree societies were split into different roles, such as the Chief, which was the title Sweet Grass held. There were also village elders and warriors. There typically was a large number of warriors within a band and these men held extremely high prestige.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=111|language=en}}</ref>
Cree religion believed in a single powerful creator which they based their ideology and ceremonies on.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=157|language=en}}</ref> This figure held no real identity and did not appear to anyone in visions or contact.<ref name=":6" /> However, this almighty creator appeared to individuals through various sprits such as the bear and horse.<ref name=":6" /> Sweet Grass’ spiritual helper was the mosquito, which he would often seek for guidance.<ref name=":15"/> He believed that the insect had taken pity on him which guided him to become a chief.<ref name=":15"/> The Cree believe that the creator spirit was in every living thing around them.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=157–158|language=en}}</ref> An individual acquired a spiritual helper after they appeared to them in a vision.<ref name=":8" /> This spirit did not provide aid or direct help in anyway but instead provided guidance.<ref name=":8" /> The Cree believe that every individual has a soul which is located at the back of their neck.<ref name=":9">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=158|language=en}}</ref> The soul was able to leave the body during visions where it would accompany their spiritual helper.<ref name=":9" /> After death, the soul would wonder the earth for four days, and then would travel to the land of the dead, which was believed to be in the Milky Way.<ref name=":9" />
===Position as Chief===
The position of chief within the Cree varied from tribe to tribe and each had varying levels of authority over the band.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David|publisher=Canadian Plains Research Center|year=1979|isbn=978-0-88977-013-3|location=Regina|pages=109}}</ref> Chiefs within Cree society were chosen by the consent of the band. While it sometimes would go the to the eldest son of the previous chief, an incompetent man would not be given the position. A chief needed to be an active leader both in peace and war. It was required to distinguish themselves during a war, as a provider, and as a generous giver to gain this position.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David|publisher=Canadian Plains Research Center|year=1979|isbn=978-0-88977-013-3|location=Regina|pages=51}}</ref> The most vital contributions of a chief was to keep the peace during the day to day living by settling arguments between the other members of the band. Sweet Grass understood the sacrifices that needed to be made for the bettering of the band. During one hunt Sweetgrass's horse was unable to remain calm, which was affecting the hunting of buffalo. Despite it being a highly valuable horse Sweetgrass traded it for an inferior one, understanding the importance of the group over the individual.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David|publisher=Canadian Plains Research Centre|year=1979|isbn=978-0-88977-013-3|location=Regina|pages=107}}</ref> It was not uncommon for there to be more than one chief who would have various levels of prestige. The amount of power wielded by Cree chiefs varied from person to person. Sweet Grass during the signing of the treaty was one of the most well-regarded plains Cree chiefs and was given a position of importance during negotiations.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Big Bear: End of Freedom|last=Hugh|first=Dempsey|publisher=University of Regina Press|year=2006|isbn=|location=Regina|pages=57}}</ref>
===Relationship with Big Bear===
Sweet Grass often worked closely with the fellow Cree chief Big Bear. They hunted in the same territory and would often hunt and camp together.<ref name=":15"/> Sweet Grass was ten years older, so Big Bear recognized him as the superior chief.<ref name=":15"/> They bonded over sharing the characteristic of being small, but mighty warriors.<ref name=":15"/> Moreover, Big Bear was part Ojibwa which meant both chiefs were not completely Cree.<ref name=":15"/> Big Bear admired Sweet Grass for his bravery and guidance that he would often receive from his spiritual helper.<ref name=":15"/> Both Chiefs would work together in multiple raids on the Blackfoot. An example of this would be when Sweet Grass and Big Bear assembled 18 Cree warriors that attempted to raid Blackfoot hunting territory.<ref name=":15"/> After being forced to set up camp along a river due to a snow storm, a member of their war party left to collect food and spotted a lone member of the Blackfoot on foot rounding up horses.<ref name=":15"/> Upon reporting his sighting back to the others, they decide to kill the man and steal his horses.<ref name=":10">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=7UBUF3X5QPQC|title=Big Bear: The End of Freedom|last=Dempsey|first=Hugh A.|date=2006|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889771963|location=|pages=30|language=en}}</ref> The attempted raid went wrong as Sweet Grass and Big Bear nearly stumbled upon Blackfoot main camp.<ref name=":10" /> Days of fighting ensued however, both chiefs managed to survive.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=7UBUF3X5QPQC|title=Big Bear: The End of Freedom|last=Dempsey|first=Hugh A.|date=2006|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889771963|location=|pages=31|language=en}}</ref>
===Buffalo Hunting and Fur Trade===
Buffalo hunting and fur trading were a vital part of Cree survival. Cree Tribes would move according to their migration habits. At the beginning of 1870, buffalo were plentiful within the plains.<ref name=":11">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=51|language=en}}</ref> In 1870, there were hundreds of thousands, which provided an immense amount of resources for the Cree to a point where they were able to only take the choice parts of the Buffalo.<ref name=":11" /> However, as European settlers came to the plains, that number dwindled significantly. In 1881, there was only a couple hundred Buffalo left within the plains.<ref name=":11" /> The Cree relied on the buffalo so heavily that they were pushed to a point of starvation.<ref name=":11" /> Additionally, as the Hudson’s Bay Company moved into the prairies, the fur trade offered an extremely important source of income and goods for the Cree. However, over-trapping forced tribes to move west to find suitable forest areas.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0807Uclx7bIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: An Ethnographic, Historical, and Comparative Study|last=Mandelbaum|first=David Goodman|date=1940|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770133|location=|pages=261|language=en}}</ref> The lack of trapping territory, along with the decline of the buffalo left the Cree helpless. Both of these issues became an extremely important topic discussed in treaty negotiations which Sweet Grass was heavily involved in.
===Cree Religious Conversion===
Different tribes of the Cree held their own stories and traditions passed down orally through the generations. As Europeans began to set up colonies in North America, missionaries went among the indigenous people to spread their religion. While traditions within tribes remained significant, the Cree became more receptive to different denominations of Christianity.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Big Bear: End of Freedom|last=Dempsey|first=Hugh|publisher=University of Regina Press|year=2006|isbn=|location=Regina|pages=40}}</ref> In 1852 the priest [[Albert Lacombe|Father Lacombe]] moved to the [[Red River Colony]] with plans to live with the Metis and Cree. His goal was to spread the Roman Catholic faith to the Western parts of Canada. During this time Lacombe would become familiar with the Cree language and the culture, even writing a Cree dictionary in 1874.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Father Lacombe: Black Robe Voyageur|last=Hughes|first=Katherine|publisher=McClelland & Stewart|year=1920|isbn=|location=Toronto|pages=111}}</ref> During the 1860s he moved farther west and would come into contact with Sweet Grass and his band. With diseases and famine rampant in the Cree community, they were more receptive to new religious ideas. It was due to both Lacombe's understanding of Cree culture and the growing desperation of the Cree, he would be able to convert many of the Cree to the Roman Catholic faith. Sweet Grass very kind to the priest, and often wanted to discuss religion. In 1870 Sweetgrass allowed himself to be baptized and was given the name Abraham.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Father Lacombe: Black Robe Voyageur|last=Hughes|first=Katherine|publisher=McClelland & Stewart|year=1920|isbn=|location=Toronto|pages=190}}</ref>
== Relationship with Canadian Government == Throughout the 19th century, it appeared as though the federal government of Canada, situated in Ottawa, worked very hard to increase the dependency that aboriginal people had on it. The government wanted tribes to become more democratic in its governing of the reserves and rely less on the chiefs who traditionally were the leaders of the community.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Niemi-Bohun|first=Melanie|title=Colonial Categories and Familial Responses to Treaty and Metis Scrip Policy: The 'Edmonton and District Stragglers,' 1870–88|journal=Canadian Historical Review|language=en|volume=90|issue=1|pages=71–98|doi=10.3138/chr.90.1.71|year=2009}}</ref> Naturally, this angered many indigenous communities who were more inclined to fight back than work with the government. Sweet Grass was one of the Chiefs who was more willing to work with them. One of the requests that Sweet Grass made to the government was to teach the Cree better farming techniques.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=OhVWDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA209&lpg=PA209&dq=Wikaskokiseyin#v=onepage&q=Wikaskokiseyin&f=false|title=Illustrated History of Canada's Native People, Fourth Edition: I Have Lived Here Since the World Began|last=Ray|first=Arthur J.|date=2016-05-01|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP|isbn=9780773599581|location=|pages=209|language=en}}</ref> Another was that the government should stop supplying weapons to the Blackfeet who were his tribe’s enemy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/wikaskokiseyin_abraham_10E.html|title=Biography – WIKASKOKISEYIN, ABRAHAM – Volume X (1871-1880) – Dictionary of Canadian Biography|access-date=2018-03-29}}</ref> These were just a few of the aspects that Sweet Grass worked with the government on. The overall goal that Sweet Grass wanted to achieve was an end to factionalism that had been plaguing the Plains Cree for years.<ref name=":13" /> Sweet Grass’ hope to work with the federal government was challenged by other prominent Cree leaders.
At the time when Sweet Grass was Chief, The Canadian government had pictured what the Indigenous communities were and never changed them.<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Niemi-Bohun|first=Melanie|title=Colonial Categories and Familial Responses to Treaty and Metis Scrip Policy: The 'Edmonton and District Stragglers,' 1870–88|journal=Canadian Historical Review|language=en|volume=90|issue=1|pages=71–98|doi=10.3138/chr.90.1.71|year=2009}}</ref> This type of thinking immediately damaged Indigenous communities as they were self-governing cultures that evolved much like any other.<ref name=":14" /> Sweet Grass along with three other Chiefs attempted to get ahead of government control by meeting with the representative of the Canadian government in the west Lieutenant Governor Archibald to petition the Hudson’s Bay Company’s (HBC) sale of land to the government.<ref name=":16">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qboeDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA110&dq=treaty+6#v=snippet&q=wikaskokiseyin&f=false|title=From Treaties to Reserves: The Federal Government and Native Peoples in Territorial Alberta, 1870-1905|last=Hall|first=D. J.|date=2015|publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press|isbn=9780773545946|location=|pages=12|language=en}}</ref> This land was not the HBC’s to sell which is a problem that would occur several times to indigenous groups all over Canada.<ref name=":16" /> They also wanted the government to be held accountable for the depleted food supplies within the indigenous territories. Sweet Grass had also requested that the government provide supplies as needed so that they may sustain themselves when traditional hunting was not an option.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=qboeDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA110&dq=treaty+6#v=snippet&q=wikaskokiseyin&f=false|title=From Treaties to Reserves: The Federal Government and Native Peoples in Territorial Alberta, 1870-1905|last=Hall|first=D. J.|date=2015|publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press|isbn=9780773545946|location=|pages=12–13|language=en}}</ref> whoever was responsible for conveying these concerns did not do so effectively as many of the requests were not met, at least not when they needed it most.
=== Treaty 6 === Treaty 6 was the biggest piece of legislation between Plains Cree Leaders and the colonial government. Signed in 1876, Treaty 6 was the agreement between the government of Canada and the Indigenous people living in parts of modern-day Saskatchewan and Alberta.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9Uae4mTTyYYC&pg=PA173&dq=canada's+treaty+6#v=onepage&q=alberta&f=false|title=Aboriginal and Treaty Rights in Canada: Essays on Law, Equity, and Respect for Difference|last=Asch|first=Michael|date=1997|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=9780774805810|location=|pages=182|language=en}}</ref> Sweet Grass’ beliefs clashed with that of Big Bear who believed that a Confederacy needed to be formed as a united front in order to get the best terms for all.<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Howells|first=Coral|date=Winter 1982|title=History from a Different Angle: Narrative Strategies in The Temptations of Big Bear|url=http://resolver.scholarsportal.info.cat1.lib.trentu.ca:8080/resolve/00219894/v17i0001/161_3hfadaittobb.xml|journal=The Journal of Commonwealth Literature|volume=17 |issue=1|pages=165|via=Scholars Portal Journals}}</ref> To be fair to Big Bear, he was mindful of what the government promised as he was not invited to the original negotiation and signing of Treaty 6.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Aboriginal and Treaty Rights in Canada|last=Venne|first=Sharon|work=|publisher=UBC Press|year=1997|isbn=|location=|pages=181|chapter=Understanding Treaty 6: An Indigenous Perspective}}</ref> What Treaty 6 did deliver was more division and segregation between European settlers and Indigenous people. Indigenous people were forced to choose between living on reserves, receiving a fixed amount of money every year for the rest of their lives and trying to assimilate and lose their status.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Niemi-Bohun|first=Melanie|title=Colonial Categories and Familial Responses to Treaty and Metis Scrip Policy: The 'Edmonton and District Stragglers,' 1870–88|journal=Canadian Historical Review|language=en|volume=90|issue=1|pages=71–98|doi=10.3138/chr.90.1.71|year=2009}}</ref> The language used to refer to indigenous people who elected to not settle on reserves also did not help ease tensions. The specific word used was “stragglers” which gave the impression that the government did not see these people as any more than falling behind in Canada’s idealized picture of what life of Indigenous people would be.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Niemi-Bohun|first=Melanie|title=Colonial Categories and Familial Responses to Treaty and Metis Scrip Policy: The 'Edmonton and District Stragglers,' 1870–88|journal=Canadian Historical Review|language=en|volume=90|issue=1|pages=71–98|doi=10.3138/chr.90.1.71|year=2009}}</ref> The unpreparedness or perhaps unwillingness of the Canadian government to deal with the problems of indigenous peoples continued long after the signing of Treaty 6 but it was Sweet Grass’ firm belief that this was the best way to ensure that indigenous culture survived.<ref name=":17" />
== Tribal Conflict == The signing of Treaty 6 was not the only reason for conflict between the Cree and other prominent Indigenous tribes in the region. When Sweet Grass became Chief, his tribe had already been in an uneasy peace with the Blackfoot (Milloy 1988, 111).<ref name=":18">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=b_Cp9kGUvuwC&pg=PA101#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: Trade, Diplomacy, and War, 1790 to 1870|last=Milloy|first=John S.|date=May 1990|publisher=Univ. of Manitoba Press|isbn=9780887553837|location=|pages=111|language=en}}</ref> Sweet Grass had endeavored to maintain this peace even though many of his people resented it. As stated previously, part of what the Cree wanted to be reflected by the terms of Treaty 6 was an end to the factionalism that had pitted the younger members of the Cree community against the older Indigenous Leadership.<ref name=":13" /> The result of this factionalism was the revival of conflict between Sweet Grass’ tribe and the Blackfeet. The peak of the conflict came in 1861 when the Blackfoot had threatened to kill any Cree, Metis, or a white man that they stumbled upon.<ref name=":18" /> Whenever a Cree war party was formed to go hunting in Blackfoot territory, caution had to be exercised, especially after the threat had been established.<ref name=":15" /> Sweet Grass and Big Bear had formed a war party for this exact purpose as stated previously. Sweet Grass himself killed a Blackfoot Chief who had been using a hollow tree as a shield by shooting through it and piercing his heart.<ref name=":10" /> Although it is not impossible, it is highly unlikely that the Cree escaped from their entrapment with as few casualties as they claimed.
The Plains Cree were not always the victims of this conflict. In 1860, a member of the Plains Cree killed a Blackfoot chief which had sparked a war against them.<ref name=":18" /> Although it is not known which of the Cree Chiefs supported an unexpected attack on a Blackfoot Chief, it is known that Sweet Grass was not among them. They had sent a war party to a Blackfoot camp and killed 18 Blackfeet in addition to stealing horses.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=b_Cp9kGUvuwC&pg=PA101#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: Trade, Diplomacy, and War, 1790 to 1870|last=Milloy|first=John S.|date=May 1990|publisher=Univ. of Manitoba Press|isbn=9780887553837|location=|pages=111–112|language=en}}</ref> Some of the Plains Cree simply could not accept peace with the Blackfoot. In another instance, Sweet Grass had invited the Blackfoot into his camp in an attempt to begin a long-standing peace with them.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=TytLkRXvkWEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=voices+of+the+plains+cree#v=onepage&q=voices%20of%20the%20plains%20cree&f=false|title=Voices of the Plains Cree|last=Ahenakew|first=Edward|date=1973|publisher=University of Regina Press|isbn=9780889770836|location=|pages=34|language=en}}</ref> The result of this was more hostility from his people who had harassed Sweet Grass’ Blackfoot guests. In 1862, Sweet Grass accompanied Broken Arm, who was known for his ability to broker peace, along with fifty escorts to finally make peace with the Blackfoot.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=b_Cp9kGUvuwC&pg=PA101#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Plains Cree: Trade, Diplomacy, and War, 1790 to 1870|last=Milloy|first=John S.|date=May 1990|publisher=Univ. of Manitoba Press|isbn=9780887553837|location=|pages=112|language=en}}</ref> As history has demonstrated, peace between the Blackfoot and the Plains Cree does not last very long. Even after Treaty 6 was signed, the Blackfoot and Plains Cree continued to quarrel over hunting as the number of buffalo faded with each passing year.
==Death==
On January 11, 1877, Sweet Grass had an argument with his brother after the signing of treaty six.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nuQ7W7x1MSwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Cuthand,+Doug.+Askiwina:+A+Cree+World.+Regina,+Saskatchewan:+Coteau+Books.+2007.#v=onepage&q=sweetgrass&f=false|title=Askiwina: A Cree World|last=Cuthand|first=Doug|date=2007-04-03|publisher=Coteau Books|isbn=9781550505054|location=|pages=43|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=JuflAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA81&lpg=PA81&dq=wikaskokiseyin#v=onepage&q=wikaskokiseyin&f=false|title=Les Missions Catholiques|last=|first=|date=1877|publisher=Bureaux de la Propagation de la Foi|isbn=|location=|pages=81|language=fr}}</ref> His brother believed that they had given too much to the government in the treaty. He attempted to take the Sweet Grass’ pistol and it accidentally discharged, resulting in his death.<ref name=":12" />
==Legacy ==
Sweet Grass through both policy and action would have a lasting impact on the Plains Cree. As a well respected Cree leader during a time of strife, Sweet Grass attempted to lead his people as best as he could. By 1870 chief Sweet Grass would begin to become more integrated into Canadian society. Due to missionaries moving into the interior, there was more significant pressure to convert to European religions, which many Cree did. Sweet Grass himself converted to Catholicism in 1870, following a general shift of Cree towards Christianity. With encroaching settlers and other indigenous groups, the dwindling of traditional hunting,<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Plains Cree: Trade, Diplomacy, and, War, 1790-1870|last=Milloy|first=John|publisher=University of Manitoba Press|year=1988|isbn=978-0-88755-141-3|location=Winnipeg|pages=116}}</ref> and disease rampant,<ref>{{Cite book|title=Big Bear: End of Freedom|last=Hugh|first=Dempsey|publisher=University of Regina Press|year=2006|isbn=|location=Regina|pages=43}}</ref> Sweet Grass and his band of Cree were desperate for support. When Treaty 6 was put forward by the Canadian government in 1876, Sweetgrass was profoundly influential in bringing the Plains Cree into the agreement.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Big Bear: End of Freedom|last=Hugh|first=Dempsey|publisher=University of Regina Press|year=2006|isbn=|location=Regina|pages=72}}</ref> This would be Sweetgrass's last significant influence on his people, as he would die shortly after signing the Treaty. While the signing of the treaty can be seen as selling away indigenous rights, it did bring much-needed medication and food to the Cree who had insufficient options.
=== Treaty 6 Impacts ===
==== Short-term Effects ==== The impact of the signing of the treaty had a significant effect on Cree life for both those who signed the treaty and those who did not. Those who did began to move onto the reserve land and being affected by the agreements made in the treaty. Not all Plains Cree would sign the treaty at first, and many would become disillusioned after signing. Big Bear resisted signing of the treaty, hoping that he could hold out for a better deal with the Canadian government.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The People: A Historical Guide to the First Nations of Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba|last=Ward|first=Donald|publisher=Fifth House Publishing|year=1995|isbn=978-1-895618-56-3|location=Calgary|pages=67}}</ref> The Canadian government could hold out for longer than any of the Cree groups who were slowly dying from starvation and disease. Even though Big Bear publicly and consistently spoke against sighing treaties, by 1882 starving, he would sign Treaty 6.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Big Bear: End of Freedom|last=Hugh|first=Dempsey|publisher=University of Regina|year=2006|isbn=|location=Regina|pages=120}}</ref> After signing the treaty, some of the Cree remained unsatisfied with the situation they had been forced into. Using this discontent, Chief Wandering Spirit gathered support and began to purses more aggressive policies towards settlers. When the Metis under Louis Riel started the Northwest-Rebellion in 1885, Wandering Spirit would lead a group of Cree to raid the Frog Lake Settlement.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Loyal Till Death: Indians and the North-West Rebellion|last=Stonechild|first=Blair|last2=Waiser|first2=Bill|publisher=Fifth House Books|year=2010|isbn=|location=|pages=117–118}}</ref> The primary goal of the raid was to get supplies, but it after some pushback from the settlers it quickly became violent. The group would then move to capture Fort Pit. The fort was heavily stocked with provisions, which angered the staving Cree. After the raid, they moved back to the reserve with the captured supplies without another incident. The perpetrators of the massacre would be apprehended and tried for murder and hung in 1885.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Loyal Till Death: Indians and the Northwest-West Rebellion|last=Waiser|first=Bill|last2=Stonechild|first2=Blair|publisher=Fifth House Publishers|year=1997|isbn=978-1-895618-88-4|location=Calgary|pages=224}}</ref>
====Debate of the Treaty====
The legacy of Treaty 6 continues to affect the Cree till the modern day. Issues arise from the mixed interpretations of the Treaty by both the Indigenous groups and the Government. As this agreement is the first legal agreement between these Indigenous groups and the new Canadian government, which continued to impact and facilitate interactions between them. This has led to conflict over the clauses of the agreement. The disagreement on Treaty 6 stems from three major issues; language barriers, verbal agreements made during the negotiation, and the rights for chiefs to sign the agreement.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/treaty-6/|title=Treaty 6|last=Filice|first=Michelle|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}}</ref> In Cree cultural the chiefs do not always hold the legal right to make choices for the entire band. As the treaty process never included women in the discussion it ignored an important cultural pressure.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Venne|first=Sharon|date=1997|title=Understanding Treaty 6: An Indigenous Perspective|url=|journal=Aboriginal and Treaty Rights in Canada|volume=|pages=191|via=}}</ref> Many of the Cree who participated in the treaty were unable to understand legal English. While there was a Cree verbal translation, the Treaty was made in English. The next biggest problem comes from a lack of follow through on verbal agreements. To the Canadian delegation, the only legally binding contracts were what was written into the treaty. In Cree culture, verbal agreements hold the same amount weight as any other agreements.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Venne|first=Sharon|date=1997|title=Understanding Treaty 6: An Indigenous Perspective|url=|journal=Aboriginal and Treaty Rights in Canada|volume=|pages=192–193|via=}}</ref> Those who signed Treaty Six argue that understanding the treaty can only be understood when put into a context of the discussions that occurred during the treaty-making process. The meaning of land and the surrender of it was not entirely understood by those who were signing the agreement.<ref name=":1" /> There was limited understanding on the level of Canadian settlement that was going to happen, and limited knowledge on how indigenous people would be restricted from the land.
=== Sweet Grass's Band === When Sweet Grass died in 1877 his son was left to hold together the Band who followed his father. Under the leadership of Young Sweet Grass, the band began to fall apart due to internal conflict. At this point, Young Sweet Grass would lead a fragment of the band to join with other Cree, who had signed Treaty 6.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.batc.ca/sweetgrass/|title=Sweetgrass First Nation|website=www.batc.ca|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref> Young Sweet Grass would eventually become chief and would name the new group the Sweetgrass First Nation in honour of his father. The Sweetgrass Nation was settled into the land West of the township Battleford, Saskatchewan in 1884. From here the group made income from farming and lumber sale, supplemented with traditional methods as much as possible.<ref name=":0" /> In the years after settlement, the Sweetgrass reserve would continue to be affected by famine and disease. Many people would leave the reserve due to government policies to limit food rations. This would lead high mortality rates within the community. On the Sweetgrass reserve, the mortality rates would grow after 1885 to 185 per every 1000 people on the reserve.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Clearing the Plains: Disease, Politics of Starvations, and the loss of Aboriginal Life|last=Daschuk|first=James|publisher=University of Regina|year=2013|isbn=|location=Regina|pages=164}}</ref> The tactic of withholding food from reserves will be used by the Canadian government to force cooperation. After resisting sending children into the Canadian school system, the Cree living on the reserve received no food rations, until they capitulated.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Clearing the Plains: Disease, Politics of Staving, and the Loss of Aboriginal Life|last=Daschuk|first=James|publisher=University of Regina Press|year=2013|isbn=978-0-88977-340-0|location=Regina|pages=168}}</ref> In 2010 the Sweetgrass nation had over 1500 registered members who primarily live outside of the Sweetgrass Reserve.<ref name=":0" />

{{Infobox person | name = Tim Nolan | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|2|5}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[United States]] | other_names = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump campaign official]] | notable_works = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] | criminal_charge = rape, human trafficking, witness tampering, prostitution | criminal_penalty = 20 years [[imprisonment]] }} '''Timothy L. Nolan''' (born 5 February 1947) is a registered sex offender and an American former state district court judge, a former leader in the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and a former Campbell County chairman of [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]] in [[Kentucky]]. On February 9, 2018, he pled guilty to 19 counts of child sex trafficking and human trafficking: on February 11, 2018 he was sentenced to serve 20 years in prison.<ref>[http://thesource.com/2018/02/11/donald-trumps-former-campaign-manger-tim-nolan-sentence-to-twenty-years-in-prison-for-child-sex-trafficking/ DONALD TRUMP'S FORMER CAMPAIGN MANAGER TIM NOLAN SENTENCED TO 20 YEARS IN PRISON FOR CHILD SEX TRAFFICKING]</ref><ref>[https://www.rawstory.com/2018/02/ex-judge-gets-20-years-sexual-abuse-trafficking-teens-serving-trump-campaign-co-chair/ Trump campaign co-chair gets 20 years for sexual abuse and trafficking teens]</ref>
==Career== Nolan received [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] degrees in philosophy and geology from [[Thomas More College (Kentucky)|Thomas More College]], and a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from the [[Salmon P. Chase College of Law]].<ref name="Cincinatti-11-2-16">Chris Mayhew, [http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/campbellcounty/2016/11/02/campbell-school-boards-makeup-grabs/93207640/ Campbell school board's makeup up for grabs], ''Cincinnati.com'', (November 2, 2016).</ref> He was City Solicitor for [[Newport, Kentucky]] in 1976,<ref>"[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/103079511/ Newport Delays Flouridation]", ''The Cincinnati Enquirer'' (December 28, 1976), p. 37.</ref><ref name="Cincinatti-11-2-16"/> and in that capacity Nolan "requested that Commonwealth Attorney Lou Ball investigate [[obscenity]] violations" against a local bookstore and theater.<ref>Michael L. Williams, ''Sin City Kentucky: Newport, Kentucky's Vice Heritage and Its Legal Extinction, 1920-1991'' (2008) {{ISBN|0549859306}}.</ref>
Nolan served as a [[Kentucky District Courts|state district court]]<!--Keep as redlink, could be an article--> judge in [[Campbell County, Kentucky]] from 1978 to 1986.<ref name="cincinnati">{{cite url|url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/politics/2016/06/10/former-judge-files-suit-over-kkk-photo/85713060/|title=Former judge files suit over KKK photo|publisher=Cincinnati.com|first=Scott|last=Wartman|date=June 10, 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/local/2016/05/19/bevin-appointment-rescinded-after-facebook-slur/84611676/ Bevin appointment rescinded after Facebook slur], Courier Journal.</ref><ref>''Kentucky Bench & Bar'', vol. 44, p. 28, 1983.</ref>
==Political career== Nolan has been one of the leaders of the Republican Party in [[Kentucky]]. In 2016 he was the [[Campbell County, Kentucky]] chairman of [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]], after receiving the personal support of Donald Trump early in 2016.<ref name="Arizmendi" /><ref name="reuters"/> As a member of the Republican Party identified with the [[Tea Party movement]], and later as a supporter of Donald Trump, Nolan has often criticized the Republican leadership in Kentucky.<ref name="cincinnati" /> ''River City News'' publisher Michael Monks described Nolan as an "outspoken and controversial" political figure in Kentucky.<ref name="rs2">[http://www.rawstory.com/2017/04/gop-school-board-member-indicted-on-sex-trafficking-charges/ Former Trump Kentucky campaign chair charged with human sex trafficking of a minor], Rawstory.</ref>
In April 2016, Nolan unsuccessfully tried to remove and replace Senator and Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] as a delegate to the [[2016 Republican National Convention]] due to McConnell's lack of support for Trump.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcsh6.com/news/nation-now/trump-allies-sidelined-in-kentucky-delegate-battle/151418435|title=Trump allies sidelined in Kentucky delegate battle|first=|last=TEGNA|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="Arizmendi">Jordan Arizmendi, [http://politicalhaze.com/2017/04/rise-fall-kentucky-trump-campaign-manager/ The Rise and Fall of a Kentucky Trump Campaign Manager], Political Haze, 25 April 2017.</ref><ref name="rs2" /> On May 17, 2016 Nolan was appointed by Governor [[Matt Bevin]] as one of the four members of the first Kentucky Boxing and Wrestling Commission for a term expiring in May 2019,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bluegrassmma.com/2016/05/governor-creates-new-kentucky-boxing-wrestling-commission/|title=Governor creates new Kentucky Boxing and Wrestling Commission|date=May 17, 2016|publisher=}}</ref> but was removed from office days later due to controversy over a social media post.<ref name="rs2" />
In August 2016, Nolan filed to run for a seat on the Campbell County School Board.<ref name="Mayhew">{{cite url|url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/campbellcounty/2016/08/09/campbell-candidates-file-forelectedoffices/88487116/|title=School board tops Campbell County election filings|first=Chris|last=Mayhew|publisher=Cincinnati.com|date=August 9, 2016}}</ref> He ran on a platform of "eliminating property tax revenue for schools gradually" and finding other ways to fund education, such as selling [[naming rights]] to schools, and advocated state-supported [[school vouchers]] and raising teacher salaries.<ref name="Mayhew"/> Nolan won election to the school board in November 2016, defeating incumbent Rich Mason.<ref>{{cite url|url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/boone-county/2016/11/07/live-reports-northern-kentucky-election-day/93426296/|title=Campbell County Schools Board of Education District 5 challenger Timothy Nolan unseated incumbent Rich Mason}}</ref> Nolan was noted as continuing to serve on the school board when being "charged with human trafficking" on May 2, 2017,<ref name="reuters">{{cite url|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trafficking-lawsuit-idUSKBN17Y299|title=Ex-Trump campaign official charged with human trafficking|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=May 2, 2017}}</ref> but resigned from the position on May 4 after being "indicted on nine felony and two misdemeanor counts".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fox19.com/story/35345653/former-campbell-county-judge-indicted-by-ky-attorney-general|title=Former Campbell County judge indicted on rape, human trafficking charges|publisher=FOX19 Digital Media|date=May 4, 2017}}</ref>
==Criminal charges==
In 2017, Nolan was charged with 28 felonies including charges of [[rape]], [[human trafficking]], [[witness tampering]], [[prostitution]], unlawful transaction with a minor and [[sodomy]]. There were 22 victims, including eight juveniles.<ref name="reuters"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/2017/09/14/tim-nolan-indicted-more-charges-going-back-50-years/666210001/|title=Former Campbell County Judge Tim Nolan indicted on more charges going back 50 years|date=September 14, 2017|publisher=cincinnati.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/04/24/trump-supporting-ex-judge-arrested-for-child-sex-crime Trump Supporting Ex-Judge Arrested for Child Sex Crime], The Daily Beast.</ref><ref>[https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/kentucky/articles/2017-04-21/ex-kentucky-district-judge-charged-with-human-trafficking Ex-Kentucky District Judge Charged With Human Trafficking], US News & World Report/Associated Press.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lex18.com/story/35733706/former-judge-indicted-on-additional-felony-charges|title=Former Judge Indicted On Additional Felony Charges|date=June 23, 2017|publisher=Lex18 NBC}}</ref>
Nolan initially pled not guilty to the charges on May 12, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/kentucky/articles/2017-05-12/prosecutor-sex-charges-against-former-judge-cover-9-victims|title=Prosecutor: Sex Charges Against Former Judge Cover 9 Victims|publisher=Associated Press|date=May 12, 2017}}</ref> On February 9, 2018 at age 71, he pled guilty to 21 counts going back to 2004 and included 19 victims including juveniles. The agreement called for 20 years in prison and to pay a $100K fine. He entered an [[Alford plea]] for some charges which means he doesn't admit to committing the act but believes the evidence is too strong for him to prevail at trial. The counts indicated he engaged in human trafficking, providing drugs and alcohol to minors in exchange for sex as well as threatening arrest and eviction unless sex acts were performed.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wartman|first1=Scott|title=Ex-Campbell County Judge Timothy Nolan to serve 20 years, pay $100K fine after plea|url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/crime/crime-and-courts/2018/02/09/ex-campbell-county-judge-timothy-nolan-serve-20-years-pay-100-k-fine-sex-trafficking-plea/323187002/|accessdate=9 February 2018|agency=The Enquirer|date=9 February 2018}}</ref>
