Bishop Boyd Carpenter as caricatured by Spy ([[Leslie Ward]]) in ''[[Vanity Fair (British magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', March 1906 |birth_date = {{Birth date|1841|03|26|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Liverpool]], [[England]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1918|10|26|1841|03|26|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Westminster]], [[England]] |residence = [[London]], [[England]] |occupation = [[Anglican]] [[cleric]] |years_active = 1878–1918 |parents = {{unbulleted list|Henry Carpenter|Hester Boyd}} |spouse = {{unbulleted list|Harriet Charlotte Peers|Annie Maude Gardner}} |relations = {{unbulleted list|[[Archibald Boyd]] (uncle)|[[Archibald Boyd-Carpenter|Sir Archibald Boyd-Carpenter]] (son)|[[Francis Wentworth-Sheilds]] (son-in-law)|[[John Boyd-Carpenter, Baron Boyd-Carpenter|The Lord Boyd-Carpenter]] (grandson)|Sir Thomas Boyd-Carpenter (great-grandson)|[[Sarah Hogg, Viscountess Hailsham|The Viscountess Hailsham]] (great-granddaughter)|William Boyd-Carpenter (son)|[[Henry Boyd-Carpenter|Sir Henry Boyd-Carpenter]] (great-grandson)|[[John William Oliver]] (great-great-grandson)}} }} ''' William Boyd Carpenter''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|KCVO}} (26 March 1841, [[Liverpool]] – 26 October 1918, [[Westminster]]) was a [[Church of England]] [[cleric]] who became [[Bishop of Ripon (modern diocese)|Bishop of Ripon]] and court chaplain to [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]]. ==Background== William Boyd Carpenter was the second son of the Revd Henry Carpenter of Liverpool, [[perpetual curate]] of [[St Michael's Church, Aigburth]], who married (marriage licence 1837 in Derry) Hester Boyd of [[Derry]], sister of [[Archibald Boyd]], Dean of Exeter.David Morris, [http://www.galtoninstitute.org.uk/Newsletters/GINL0506/bishop_boyd_carpenter.htm 'Bishop Boyd Carpenter: Sheep or Shepherd in the Eugenics Movement?'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106061452/http://www.galtoninstitute.org.uk/Newsletters/GINL0506/bishop_boyd_carpenter.htm |date=6 January 2009 }}, ''The Galton Institute Newsletter'', 55, June 2005 Her father was Archibald Boyd (born about 1764 of Saint Leonards, Shoreditch, London, England), who married Sarah Bodden there on 13 July 1789.{{cite web|title=Sarah Boyd (Bodden)|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Sarah-Boyd/6000000038132873223|work=[[Geni.com|Geni]]|accessdate=22 May 2016|language=English}} Carpenter was the uncle of Mrs Henry Williams of Moor Park House, [[Beckwithshaw]], North Yorkshire. In 1897 he consecrated [[Church of St Michael and All Angels, Beckwithshaw|St Michaels and All Angels Church]] at Beckwithshaw, after she and her husband had funded its construction.''[[Newspapers of Yorkshire|Yorkshire Gazette]]'', 2 October 1886: "Ecclesiastical news"[http://www.cottingleyconnect.org.uk/church.shtml Cottingley Connect: St Michael and All Angels church] Retrieved 17 January 2014''[[Leeds Times]]'', Saturday 2 October 1886 ==Education and career== Carpenter was educated at the [[Royal Institution]], Liverpool, and [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge|St Catharine's College]], [[Cambridge University|Cambridge]], and was appointed [[Hulsean lectures|Hulsean lecturer]] at Cambridge in 1878.{{acad|id=CRPR860WB|name=Carpenter, William Boyd}} He held several [[curate|curacies]], was [[vicar]] of Christ Church, [[Lancaster Gate]], from 1879 to 1884, [[Canon (priest)|canon]] of [[Windsor, Berkshire|Windsor]] in 1882–84, and after 1884 [[Bishop of Ripon (modern diocese)|Bishop of Ripon]]. In 1887 he was appointed [[Bampton lectures|Bampton lecturer]] at [[University of Oxford|Oxford]], and in 1895 pastoral lecturer on [[theology]] at Cambridge. In June 1901, he received an honorary [[Doctor of Divinity|doctorate of Divinity]] from the [[University of Glasgow]].{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Glasgow University jubilee |day_of_week=Friday |date=14 June 1901 |page_number=10 |issue=36481| }} In 1904 and 1913 he visited the [[United States]] and delivered the Noble lectures at [[Harvard University|Harvard]]. He was [[Clerk of the Closet|chaplain in ordinary]] to [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]], [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|Edward VII]], and [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]]. He resigned his see in 1911 on the grounds of ill-health and became a canon and sub-dean of [[Westminster Abbey|Westminster]]. He was interested in [[eugenics|eugenic]] issues and served as President of the [[Society for Psychical Research]] in 1912.H. D. A. Major, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/32305 ‘Carpenter, William Boyd (1841–1918)’], rev. H. C. G. Matthew, ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 14 April 2009 He was appointed [[Clerk of the Closet]] from 1903 to 1918. ==Publications== [[Image:William Boyd Carpenter 008jpg.jpg|thumb|right|William Boyd Carpenter, 1889]] His publications include: * ''Commentary on Revelation'' (1879) * ''Permanent Elements of Religion'' (Bampton lectures, 1889) * ''Popular History of the Church of England'' (1900) * ''Witness to the Influence of Christ'' (1905) * ''Some Pages of my Life'' (1911) * ''Life's Tangled Thread'' (1912) * ''The Apology of Experience'' (1913) * ''The Burning Bush and Other Sermons. '' (1893) ==Correspondence with Alexandra Feodorovna== {{Context|section|date=August 2015}} William Boyd-Carpenter corresponded with the last empress of Russia, [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)]]. "In early 1895 she wrote to William Boyd-Carpenter, who as Bishop of Ripon was also court chaplain to her grandmother Queen Victoria, that she was trying hard to come to terms with external trappings of her new faith. ‘Now that I am more used to hear the Russian language I can understand the service so much better, and many things have become clear to me and comprehensible which at first rather startled me. The singing is most beautiful and edifying, only I miss the sermons, which are never preached in the Imperial chapels..."Janet Ashton, [http://www.alexanderpalace.org/palace/godinallthings.html "God in all things": the religious beliefs of Russia’s last empress and their personal and political context]{{Long quote|date=August 2015}} ==Family== In 1864 Carpenter married his first wife, Harriet Charlotte Peers (daughter of the Rev. J. W. Peers, of Chislehampton), who bore him eight children: * Henry John Boyd-Carpenter (1865-1923), Inspector-General of schools in [[Egypt]] * Jessie Peers Boyd-Carpenter (b. 1866), a nurse at [[St Thomas' Hospital]] who married Dr. William John Edwin Davies * Minnie Boyd-Carpenter (b. 1867), who married the Rev. Richard Bartram Tollinton * Mary Boyd-Carpenter (b. 1868) * William Boyd Boyd-Carpenter (b. 1869), who married Lina Frederica Marie Mordwinoff Haydon * Annie Boyd-Carpenter (1870-1927), who married the Rt. Rev. [[Wentworth Francis Wentworth-Sheilds|Francis Wentworth-Sheilds]], [[Anglican Diocese of Armidale|Bishop of Armidale]] * John Peers Boyd-Carpenter (1871-1936), army officer and colonial administrator * [[Archibald Boyd-Carpenter|Sir Archibald Boyd Boyd-Carpenter]] (1873-1937), [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP and father of [[John Boyd-Carpenter, Baron Boyd-Carpenter|John Archibald Boyd-Carpenter (Baron Boyd-Carpenter)]], also a Conservative MP Harriet died in 1887 and in 1883 Carpenter married his second wife, Annie Maude Gardner (daughter of W. W. Gardner), who bore him a further four children:Charles Mosley, editor, ''Burke's Peerage and Baronetage'', 106th edition, 2 volumes (Crans, Switzerland: Burke's Peerage (Genealogical Books) Ltd, 1999), volume 1, page 344. Hereinafter cited as Burke's Peerage and Baronetage, 106th edition. * Victoria Alexandrina Boyd-Carpenter (1884-1885) * Beatrice Victoria Margaret Boyd-Carpenter (1885-1977), who married the Rev. Frederick Stanley Pears Lynn Girdlestone, who had been her father's chaplain at Ripon * Victor Charles Douglas Boyd-Carpenter (1887-1916), a Lieutenant in the [[Royal Engineers]] * Hester Macneil Boyd-Carpenter (1893-1960), who married Dr. Arthur Ferguson MacCallan, an ophthalmologist who worked in [[Egypt]] Carpenter's other descendants include: * [[John Boyd-Carpenter, Baron Boyd-Carpenter|John Archibald Boyd-Carpenter, Baron Boyd-Carpenter]] (1908-1998), a Conservative MP * Michael Boyd-Carpenter (b. 1932), senior partner at Joseph Sebag & Co, stockbrokers{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * Sir [[Thomas Boyd-Carpenter|Thomas Patrick John Boyd-Carpenter]] (b. 1938), an army officer * Sir [[Henry Boyd-Carpenter]] KCVO (b. 1939), senior partner at [[Farrer & Co]], the royal solicitors{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} * [[Sarah Hogg, Viscountess Hailsham|Sarah Elizabeth Mary Boyd-Carpenter, Baroness Hogg]] (b. 1946), a politician and wife of [[Douglas Hogg]] * [[Stephen Oliver (composer)|Stephen Michael Harding Oliver]] (1950-1992), a composer * [[John Oliver (comedian)|John William Oliver]] (b. 1977), a comedianhttp://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/51267 ==Ancestry== [[File:Carpenter Knight.JPG|thumb|150px|left| Sample of a medieval knight with an early Carpenter Coat of Arms on shield.]] "Life of Lord George Carpenter", published in 1736 (five years before Carpenter's death) is stored in the [[British Museum]]. It states that he was a son of Warncomb Carpenter, who was the sixth son of Thomas Carpenter, Esq., from Holme in the parish of [[Dilwyn]], [[Herefordshire]]. The family had owned land there for over 400 years, proof of their being there by 1300.{{cite journal | url=http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/c/a/r/John-R-Carpenter/FILE/0023text.txt | title=The Carpenter Family of England and the United States | author=Carpenter, J. Hatton | journal=Utah Genealogical and Historical Magazine | date=April 1925 | volume=16 | issue=2 | pages=60–70 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140917102535/http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/c/a/r/John-R-Carpenter/FILE/0023text.txt | archive-date=17 September 2014}} The family bore [[Coat of arms|arms]] with a [[blazon]] reading "Paly of six, argent and gules, on a chevron azure, 3 cross crosslets or." The 3 cross crosslets show that an ancestor had been in the [[Crusades]] or was a Crusader, possibly [[William, Count of Melun|William de Melun]]. Their motto was ''Per acuta belli'' ("Through the asperities of war"). There is no direct male-to-male Carpenter descent connecting Lord George Carpenter and Sir William Boyd Carpenter. The family connection is by marriage through women in the family.Carpenter, John R. ''Carpenters' Encyclopedia of Carpenters 2009'' (DVD format). Lord George is RIN 11685. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{NIE}} ==External links== {{Commons category|William Boyd Carpenter}} {{Portal|Biography}} * [http://anglicanhistory.org/england/wbcarpenter/ Bibliographic directory of William Boyd Carpenter] from [[Project Canterbury]] * {{Gutenberg author | id=Carpenter,+William+Boyd }} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=William Boyd Carpenter |sopt=tight}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090106061452/http://www.galtoninstitute.org.uk/Newsletters/GINL0506/bishop_boyd_carpenter.htm "Bishop Boyd Carpenter: Sheep or Shepherd in the Eugenics Movement?"] by David Morris, ''[[Galton Institute]] Newsletter'' Issue 55 (June 2005) {{S-start}} {{s-rel}} {{s-bef|before=[[Robert Bickersteth (bishop)|Robert Bickersteth]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Bishop of Ripon (modern diocese)|Bishop of Ripon]]|years=1884–1912}} {{s-aft|after=[[Thomas Wortley Drury]]}} {{S-end}} {{Bishops of Ripon (modern diocese)}} {{Clerks of the Closet}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boyd Carpenter, William}} [[Category:1841 births]] [[Category:1918 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century English Anglican priests]] [[Category:Alumni of St Catharine's College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Bishops of Ripon (modern diocese)]] [[Category:Boyd-Carpenter family]] [[Category:Canons of Westminster]] [[Category:Canons of Windsor]] [[Category:Clerks of the Closet]] [[Category:English religious writers]] [[Category:Harvard University people]] [[Category:Honorary Chaplains to the Queen]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] [[Category:Parapsychologists]]
